    Emerging Trends in Flow Chemistry and Applications to the Pharmaceutical Industry

    • Andrew R. Bogdan*
      Andrew R. Bogdan
      Discovery Chemistry and Technology, AbbVie, Inc. 1 North Waukegan Road, North Chicago, Illinois 60064, United States
      *E-mail: [emailÂ protected]. Phone: (847) 938-5363.
      More by Andrew R. Bogdan
      View Biography
      http://orcid.org/0000-0003-0913-0779

    • Amanda W. Dombrowski
      Amanda W. Dombrowski
      Discovery Chemistry and Technology, AbbVie, Inc. 1 North Waukegan Road, North Chicago, Illinois 60064, United States
      More by Amanda W. Dombrowski
      View Biography

    Abstract

    The field of flow chemistry has garnered considerable attention over the past 2 decades. This Perspective highlights many recent advances in the field of flow chemistry and discusses applications to the pharmaceutical industry, from discovery to manufacturing. From a synthetic perspective, a number of new enabling technologies are providing more rationale to run reactions in flow over batch techniques. Additionally, highly automated flow synthesis platforms have been developed with broad applicability across the pharmaceutical industry, ranging from advancing medicinal chemistry programs to self-optimizing synthetic routes. A combination of simplified and automated systems is discussed, demonstrating how flow chemistry solutions can be tailored to fit the specific needs of a project.

    1. Introduction

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    Within the increasingly competitive landscape of the pharmaceutical industry exists a never-ending need to develop new, enabling technologies to facilitate the discovery of an active pharmaceutical ingredient (API) to streamline its manufacturing route. One such technology often applied is flow chemistry, in which reactions are carried out within tubing or microchannels as opposed to standard batch reactors. Over the past 2 decades, significant advances in the field of flow chemistry, in both academic and industrial settings, have permitted chemistries unachievable via conventional batch methods and helped to improve the manufacturing of APIs via continuous processing. While the majority of flow chemistry examples highlight applications to process or manufacturing environments, additional examples demonstrate the utility of flow chemistry in a drug discovery environment. Flow technologies can range from simplified systems to highly automated platforms. Regardless of application or complexity, however, these technologies have the potential to make significant impact in the industry.
    The numerous benefits of running reactions in flow are well-documented in a number of comprehensive reviews.(1â13) While there are a multitude of benefits of flow chemistry, it is not a solution to all chemistry problems and not all reactions necessarily benefit from being run in flow. Deciding to run reactions in flow depends on a number of variables, such as the importance of heat transfer and mixing and what sources of energy are being used. If reaction outcomes are greatly affected by slight fluctuations in these variables, flow chemistry may prove to be beneficial. Over the past few years, there have been considerable advances in the field that highlight many additional advantages of running reactions in flow. In this Perspective, we provide an overview of many advances in flow chemistry over the past 8 years that demonstrate its broad applicability to the pharmaceutical industry. Albeit far from comprehensive, we will discuss many enabling flow technologies that expand the list of reasons to favor running reactions in flow over batch. Finally, we outline many recent advances in flow chemistry with respect to continuous processing and high-throughput methodologies. Examples of varying complexity have been chosen to show how flow reactors can be âfit-for-purposeâ, using either commercial or custom-built solutions. While barriers continue to limit the implementation of flow chemistry in some areas, we have chosen some examples that demonstrate how readily available materials can help set up flow systems with minimal investment.

    2. Flow Chemistry Applications across the Pharmaceutical Industry

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    Flow chemistry has become ubiquitous across the pharmaceutical industry, with a majority of companies having invested in this technology. Major pharmaceutical companies and contract manufacturing organizations alike have made a sustained investment in flow chemistry in continuous processing for a number of years, in many cases having entire manufacturing plants dedicated to this technology.(14) A more recent trend, however, is to implement flow chemistry in a drug discovery setting.(15) While the perceived benefits of using flow chemistry vary across the different stages of the pharmaceutical industry, it has become a high-impact tool when applied appropriately (Table 1).
    Table 1. Flow Chemistry Applications across the Pharmaceutical Industry
    drug discoveryprocessÂ chemistry/manufacturing
    High/low temperature applicationsProcess intensification
    Nonstandard reaction conditions (photochemistry,Â electrochemistry,Â etc.)Hazardous reactions
    Library synthesisContinuous processing
    High-throughput reaction screeningContinuous synthesis of API intermediates
    IntegratedÂ synthesis/bioassayÂ platformsAPI manufacturing
    Building block scale-upPharmaceuticals on demand

    3. Flow Chemistry Methodology: Flow over Batch

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    As previously stated, deciding to run a reaction in flow can depend on a number of variables. There are a number of instances, however, where the choice to run a reaction in flow is more obvious. For instance, reactions run at extreme temperatures (both high and low) are beneficial to run in flow due to simplified scalability and improved reaction profiles resulting from enhanced heat transfer. Additionally, hazardous reagents and gases can be safely prepared and consumed in processes that may otherwise prove problematic on scale. Narrow reaction channels provide more efficient transfer of energy in these systems, making photochemical and electrochemical reactions more favorable to run.
    While a number of commercial flow reactors exist for the applications mentioned above, these systems can readily be custom built using equipment that is commonly present in chemistry laboratories (Table 2). A legend of common flow reactor equipment used throughout this Perspective is shown in Figure 1.

    3.1. High-Temperature Flow Chemistry

    Being able to attenuate the pressure of a flow reactor using a back-pressure regulator enables the use of elevated temperatures. A number of different methods can be used to reach these elevated temperatures, such as hot plates, gas chromatographs, or other commercial reactors. Alternative methods of heating flow reactions also exist, such as microwaves(16) or inductive heating.(17) Using a high-temperature platform such as this, solvents can be heated to temperatures well-beyond their boiling points, making it possible to use greener solvents for high-temperature mediated transformations. Furthermore, increased temperature can accelerate reactions and facilitate chemistry that is not readily attainable in batch.
    Chemists at Roche have reported examples of high-temperature flow chemistry using a custom built flow reactor. In this system, a Vapourtec R2+R4 system was used for the pumping of reagents, and a gas chromatograph oven was used to heat reactions. Chemistries demonstrated using this platform include the annulation of pyridine analogs via an intramolecular cyclization at temperatures between 250 and 310 Â°C in toluene(18) and an intermolecular process via the Kondratâeva reaction at 230 Â°C (Scheme 1).(19) In both cases a wide array of substrates could be transformed to the corresponding pyridines in modest to high yield, using a solvent at 2â3Ã its boiling point.
    A novel high-temperature indole formation in flow was developed by OâBrien and co-workers using toluene as the solvent between temperatures of 160â220 Â°C.(20) As this reaction involves heating organic azides to elevated temperatures, it is not viewed as a favorable method for synthesizing indoles due to stability issues associated with the starting materials. Using flow, however, many of the risks associated with this reaction can be mitigated. As reactor volumes are minimized, only a small amount of azide is heated at any given moment. Narrow dimensions of the flow reactor enable excellent temperature control, thus preventing runaway exotherms. At AbbVie, this methodology has been applied in the synthesis of a number of heterocycles to support drug discovery programs (Scheme 2).(21) Scale-up was carried out initially using a simplified Phoenix flow reactor that was later automated to facilitate scale-up and reaction screening (Figure 2). While traditional batch methods for running a HemetsbergerâKnittel indole formation involve the use of refluxing xylenes as the solvent, this flow methodology permits toluene to be used as the solvent instead greatly simplifying isolation.
    The Phoenix platform has similarly been applied to synthesize libraries of 2-aminoquinazoline analogs in modest to excellent yield (Scheme 3).(22) Using a high-temperature SNAr in flow, this straightforward procedure uses ethanol as the solvent at 225 Â°C, providing a greener alternative to traditional SNAr routes. Furthermore, the reaction proceeds without the addition of excess base. Library work was expanded to include 2-chloroquinoxalines and 2-chlorobenzimidazoles.
    The GouldâJacobs reaction has been studied by both the Darvas group(23,24) and AbbVie(25) to synthesize fused pyrimidinone and quinolone type structures. Using the Phoenix, novel aromatic and heterocyclic structures were synthesized at 350 Â°C in just 0.45 min (Scheme 4). Tsoung and co-workers at AbbVie further optimized this high-temperature heterocycle formation to provide a general set of reaction conditions where the selectivity of carbonylated and decarbonylated materials could be easily controlled at 390 Â°C (Scheme 5).(25)
    The Phoenix was applied to the DielsâAlder reaction. In this method, high-temperature ringâopening of benzocyclobutanes and benzothiopene-2,2-dioxides are facilitated by heating to 350 Â°C, resulting in an o-diquinomethane diene 1 (Scheme 6).(26) The diene was trapped with a wide variety of dienophiles in both intra- and intermolecular fashion. It is also worth noting that for this DielsâAlder, along with the GouldâJacobs couplings, THF was used as the solvent at temperatures between 350 and 390 Â°C. Using flow, the requirement for using high-boiling solvents for these transformations has been mitigated.
    A final application of the Phoenix is in the high-temperature N-Boc-deprotection of a broad series of amines.(27) In this simplified process, starting materials were dissolved in acetonitrile and injected into the flow reactor for 2 min at 300 Â°C. No additional reagents were required to facilitate the deprotection. Final deprotected amines were isolated in quantitative yield simply by solvent removal (Scheme 7). This technique was applied to multiple syntheses using an intermediate Boc-deprotection in the Phoenix. These pharmaceutically relevant procedures allow a three-step process to be completed in a matter of minutes to generate >180 mg of final material without the need for intermediate purifications or workups (Scheme 8).
    The Buchwald group has demonstrated a high-temperature mediated trifluoromethylation of aryl iodides using potassium trifluoroacetate (Scheme 9).(28) This procedure uses readily available equipment and reagents to facilitate the reaction, making it a very easy process to adapt in a laboratory. Additionally, the authors demonstrated how gram quantities of material could be synthesized in a relatively rapid manner.
    High-temperature applications are not restricted to laboratory scale. Amann and co-workers have reported a flow-mediated Overman rearrangement at 220 Â°C to synthesize an intermediate 2 for an API under development by Actellion Pharmaceuticals (Scheme 10).(29) After development, this procedure was capable of being carried out on >95 kg of the starting material to synthesize the final material in quantitative yield after 84 h of continuous processing.

    3.2. Flash Chemistry and Cryogenic Flow Chemistry

    At the opposite end of the temperature spectrum, there have been many demonstrated uses for running cryogenic reactions in flow. Due to the superb heat-transfer associated with flow reactors, chemical reactions can be efficiently maintained at low temperatures, and rapid exotherms that may prove problematic in batch reactors can be easily handled in flow. High surface-area-to-volume ratios lead to excellent heat transfer and greater temperature control. For instance, when cooling a batch reactor (whether it be a round-bottom flask or a large tank reactor), more efficient heat transfer occurs at the outside of the vessel, where there is direct contact with the coolant. As a result, there are likely to be temperature gradients toward the inner portions of the reactor. In contrast, envision cooling tubing that is on the order of millimeters in diameter. Narrow dimensions will result in efficient cooling and fewer hotspots. As a result, low temperature reactions can be run very cleanly on scale using flow. Central to the success of this chemistry is the highly efficient mixing that occurs by either the use of high flow rates or the use of mixers. A number of options for mixing reactions in flow exist, ranging from straightforward T-mixers to more elaborate static mixers (Figure 3). Many cryogenic reactions fall under the realm of flash chemistry, a type of chemical transformation occurring within very short timeframes (<1 s).(30) Using this technique, reactive species are generated and consumed in a rapid manner, permitting high-yielding transformations otherwise difficult to obtain via batch processes.

    3.2.1. Î±-Ketoamide Formation

    In a recent example of flash chemistry by the Yoshida group, carbamoyl anions are generated in flow and reacted with chloroformates, generating Î±-ketoamides in modest to excellent yield.(31) The technology was applied to the synthesis of a key intermediate 3 in the synthesis of a sodium channel blocker GW356194 (Scheme 11). For a four-step process, the total residence time of the reaction was <7 s, demonstrating the potentially high-throughput nature of this chemistry. If products are being synthesized on the time scale of seconds, there is high applicability of this work to scale up.

    3.2.2. LithiationâBorylation

    A common theme in the flow literature is generating complex boronates via a lithiationâborylation cascade. The Ley group, in collaboration with Cambridge Reactor Design and Dow Chemical, has developed a flow system for the synthesis of (4-chloro-2-fluoro-3-methoxyphenyl)boronic acid 4. Using fluorine-directed ortho-lithiation from 2-chloro-6-fluoroanisole 5, 4 could be synthesized in multigram quantities (Scheme 12).(32,33) Using a low temperature reactor, the Polar Bear, large scale continuous processing was possible through rigorous control of reaction parameters, such as mixing, cooling and exotherm minimization. This system was used at â50 Â°C to process 100 g of product in 7 h with an 80% yield.
    Chemists at Novartis have reported a similar flow borylation procedure. In order to scale up, the authors opted to simply increase reactor volume instead of adding parallel reactors.(34) By increasing reactor volume 6-fold and adding static mixers, this new design increases the throughput of the process from â¼5 mmol/min to â¼30 mmol/min (Figure 4). For the synthesis, both the metalation and borylation steps take place at â30 Â°C, with a combined reaction time of 1 s. Followed by a batch quenching procedure using citric acid, roughly 146 g of the target boronic acid 6 could be isolated following purification (Scheme 13). By running this custom-built flow reactor for a mere 25 min, multigram quantities of material could be prepared. Very few modifications to the system would be required to scale this process to kilogram scale, demonstrating how this chemistry can be applied from discovery to manufacturing scale.
    Takeda has also reported a lithiationâborylation sequence to generate kilograms of material of a key intermediate in the synthesis of a PI3KÎ± inhibitor 7.(35) Similar to the previous examples, very short residence times were required for the lithiation and borylation steps (Scheme 14). While optimized conditions for the reaction were found to be at â25 Â°C, scale-up runs had to be performed at 0 Â°C in order to prevent reactor clogging. The process was run for >10 h, resulting in 1.23 kg of final product 7, following workup and deprotection.

    3.2.3. DIBAL-H

    Chemists at Eisai applied flow chemistry to the manufacturing of an intermediate in the synthesis of eribulin mesylate 8.(36) Two separate cryogenic batch processes were investigated in a flow regime. In both cases, the use of flow reactors allowed the reactions to be carried out at higher temperatures than batch. Using a procedure similar to one as first reported by the Jamison group,(37) a DIBAL-H mediated reduction of an ester was carried out at â50 Â°C in flow, generating 306 g of aldehyde 9 in 87 min (Scheme 15A). Reaction time for this process was only 0.08 s. The second step was an nBuLi-mediated coupling that required â70 Â°C as the temperature in batch. Highlighting the ability of flow reactors to rapidly dissipate exotherms and provide superior control over reaction temperature, the flow coupling of sulfone 10 to aldehyde 9 proceeded with higher yields and greater selectivity when run at 10 Â°C (Scheme 15B). For this second process, the total reaction time was <5 s and compound 8 could be isolated in excellent yield.

    3.2.4. Dichloromethyllithium and Homologation

    Novartis has expanded upon their low-temperature chemistry procedures by synthesizing dichloromethyllithium 11 in a continuous flow process (Scheme 16).(38) In this process, dichloromethane 12 is deprotonated with nBuLi at â30 Â°C for 0.5 s and quenched with an electrophile. Scale-ups were run for 5 min, generating gram quantities of various dichlorocarbinols in excellent yield. Additionally, a series of boronic pinacol esters could be homologated using a similar procedure.
    A continuous flow process for the Matteson homologation step in the synthesis of vaborbactam has been reported (Scheme 17).(39) Similar to the previous example, hazards associated with the preparation of dichloromethyllithium 11 are mitigated by the use of a flow reactor. First, nBuLi in heptane was diluted with THF to prevent precipitation at â60 Â°C and mixed with a solution of dichloromethane 12 in THF, forming dichloromethyllithium 11. The boronate 13 in 10:1 THF/heptane was mixed with the dichloromethyllithium, and the output was collected in a batch reactor containing ZnCl2 in THF at â20 Â°C. The rearrangement is facilitated by ZnCl2, a Lewis acid, which is believed to improve the diastereoselectivity of the reaction by transition state chelation. Using this process, 880 kg of the desired boronate 14 was formed in 12 GMP batches with an average yield of 89%.

    3.2.5. Carboxylation

    After difficulties with batch processing, a continuous flow process for the carboxylation step in the synthesis of lifitegrast was developed by SARcode (Scheme 18).(40,41) A solution of TMEDA and dichloride intermediate 15 was mixed with a solution of nBuLi at â78 Â°C. The resultant anion species was mixed with CO2 gas in flow, and the output was collected and quenched with HCl in batch mode to form the desired carboxylic acid 16. This process reproducibly gave the desired product 16 in high purity with yields of 88â91% on 4â5 kg scale.

    3.2.6. Formylation

    Merck scientists utilized a continuous flow process for a key formylation step during the kilogram-scale synthesis of an Akt kinase inhibitor.(42) Due to gelling issues that arose when scaling the batch process, performing the formylation step in flow was evaluated (Scheme 19). Mixing the tert-butyl (2-bromo-6-chloropyridin-3-yl)carbamate with MeLi in THF at â60 Â°C preformed the anion 17, which was pumped into the flow reactor using a peristaltic pump. This stream was mixed with nBuLi through a T-connector into a static line mixer. The stream exiting this mixer contained the dianion which was mixed with DMF in THF through a T-connector into another static mixer. Although the flow setup was placed in a â78 Â°C bath, the recorded temperatures for each stage varied from â55 to â70 Â°C. The solution was quenched in batch mode by collecting the outflow in a flask containing acetic acid, TBME, and water to give the desired compound 18 in a 63% isolated yield. The synthesis of the aldehyde took <5 s to complete using the custom setup shown in Figure 5.

    3.2.7. Mannich-Type Addition

    The development of a pilot-plant scale continuous flow method for the synthesis of a key precusor to verubecestat has been reported by Merck.(43,44) After developing a continuous flow process, issues with long-term performance led the authors to pursue a hybrid batch-flow procedure. The starting lithium anion 20 was preformed in batch and flowed into a static mixer where it was mixed with the ketimine 19. Due to stability issues with the starting lithium anion 20, the batch deprotonation was performed at â20 Â°C to minimize decomposition of the intermediate. Furthermore, the lithium anion 20 also showed solubility issues at â20 Â°C, which were solved by the addition of DMPU prior to flowing the solution into the static mixer. During the addition of the organolithium species to the chiral ketimine 19, mixing efficiency was found to be an important parameter at the lab scale and was tested by exploring the flow rate and different types of mixers on the plant scale. The final optimized process gave 88% assay yield of the intermediate 21 on >100 kg scale (Scheme 20).

    3.2.8. Iron-Catalyzed Kumada Coupling

    Chemists at Boehringer-Ingelheim have reported the development of a low-temperature, continuous flow process to enable the iron-catalyzed Kumada coupling of a 2-chloropyrazine 22 and an arylmagnesium bromide 23 (Scheme 21).(45) This process was able to solve the problems seen in the batch process, namely, decomposition of the heteroaryl chloride and catalyst deactivation (proposed to be caused by catalyst decomposition or product inhibition). Studies showed that the Grignard addition needed to be rapid, and the temperature needed to be well controlled in order to maximize the reaction yield. In flow, it was determined that â20 Â°C was the optimal reaction temperature and a 1â4 min residence time. The flow process was highly reproducible and scalable with improved yields while using lower catalyst loadings. Over 10 h, 0.6 kg of 2-chloropyrazine was transformed into the desired product 24 with an 82% isolated yield.
    The application of low-temperature flow chemistry to the pharmaceutical industry will likely only expand as numerous syntheses have shown great promise in comparison to batch techniques. Reactions such as these can be rapidly scaled to kilogram quantities in a very short time frame.

    3.3. In Situ Generation of Hazardous or Unstable Reagents/Intermediates

    By using flow chemistry, there is the added benefit of being able to generate reagents in situ to be used immediately in subsequent reaction steps. This is of high-value especially when these reagents either are hazardous or are prone to decomposition upon storage. As a result, flow chemistry is often relied upon when a synthetic route calls for such materials, especially within the manufacturing sector.

    3.3.1. Vilsmeier Reagent

    One such example involves the generation of Vilsmeier reagents in flow. Rutjes and co-workers have utilized Vilsmeier reagents 25 in flow, specifically in the formylation of electron-rich arenes (Scheme 22A).(46) In this work, dimethylformamide (DMF) and phosphorus oxychloride (POCl3) are mixed in flow before being mixed with the substrate to be formylated. Using this procedure, formylated pyrrole 26 could be synthesized in gram quantities per hour. Similarly, the Buchwald group reported a similar procedure for synthesizing the Vilsmeier reagent 25 in flow, specifically in the synthesis of Î²-chloro enals 27.(47) The Î²-chloroacrolein products could further be elaborated in a multistep flow sequence to provide Î²-chloroacrylonitriles 28 or substituted pyrazoles (Scheme 22B).
    On an industrial scale, the Vilsmeier reagent 25 has been used in flow in the synthesis of Vildagliptin.(48) Using a hybrid batch-flow process, an acylated prolamide intermediate 29 was converted to cyanopryrrolidine 30 in flow using the Vilsmeier reagent 25 that has been generated on-demand. To improve mixing during dehydration, glass beads were packed into the reactor coil. Overall, the throughput of cyanopyrrolidine 30 was 5.8 kg hâ1 Lâ1 (Scheme 23). The design of this system consists of a series of readily available materials, demonstrating the relative ease of setting up systems such as this (Figure 6).

    3.3.2. Phosgene

    Phosgene 31 is another hazardous reagent that has been synthesized in situ using a flow-based procedure. In work by Yasukouchi and co-workers, triphosgene 32 and tributylamine are mixed in flow, generating a phosgene solution that is immediately coupled to another substrate in flow.(49) The methodology was demonstrated to generate >60 g of chloroformate 32 adducts in under 5 min (Scheme 24). This example highlights how hazardous reagents such as phosgene 31 can be safely and efficiently prepared and reacted in flow on scale.

    3.3.3. Lithium Diisopropylamide

    Gustafsson and co-workers at AstraZeneca have described a three-step flow process toward the penultimate intermediate in the synthesis of AZD6906.(50) In this synthesis, lithium diisopropylamide (34, LDA) was synthesized in situ from nBuLi and diisopropylamine. By generation of the LDA in situ, higher concentrations could consistently be achieved and variances between commercial batches of LDA could be avoided. The LDA solution was immediately reacted with a solution of N-Boc-glycine methyl ester 35 and phosphinate 36 (Scheme 25). Using this telescoped process, 682 g of final product 37 could be obtained.

    3.3.4. Diazonium/Diazo Compounds

    Another reoccurring theme in flow chemistry is the generation of diazonium/diazo compounds and their subsequent coupling.(51) While this class of compounds is a highly versatile block, their application to large-scale processes is generally limited due to safety concerns. In flow, it is easy to generate diazo species from stable, readily available starting materials and use them directly in subsequent reaction steps, thus eliminating the need for isolate and storage.
    The Ley group has demonstrated a multistep continuous synthesis for substituted pyrazoles.(52) A series of aromatic diazonium compounds were synthesized in situ from anilines and tBuONO or NaNO2. Following reduction with ascorbic acid 38 and hydrolysis, pyrazoles are generated following condensation with a series of 1,3-dicarbonyls (Scheme 26). This example demonstrates how unstable diazo compounds can be easily managed safely in a laboratory setting using flow. Unreacted materials are quenched, and there is never an appreciable buildup of unstable material.
    Similarly, researchers at Pfizer have implemented a procedure for generating diazonium compounds in flow on production scale.(53) In this process, the diazonium compound 39 is generated again by treatment with tBuONO. To purify the reaction, the outlet stream containing 39 was subsequently mixed with water and flowed into a tank reactor, where the biphasic reaction mixture could be separated. To complete the synthesis, the aqueous layer was loaded into a tank reactor containing SnCl2 to reduce 39 to the corresponding hydrazine. After the reaction with a ketoamine, the final pyrazole product 40 could be isolated (Scheme 27). This process was run on up to a 1 kg scale of starting material, resulting in 677 g of final product 40. This example demonstrates how hazardous reagents can be safely utilized on-scale. Although a total of 4.9 mol of diazonium compound 39 was being synthesized during the scale-up run, active reaction volumes are minimized in flow, meaning that only 99 mmol of 39 was present at any given time. Conversely, if this process was carried out in batch, all 4.9 mol of 39 would be generated at once, posing a far greater safety concern.
    The Charette group has reported an alternative method for the synthesis of diazo compounds, specifically low-molecular weight diazoalkanes 41.(54) Starting with a series of hydrazones, diazoalkanes 41 could be synthesized by being passed through a packed bed of Ag2O and K2CO3 (Scheme 28). The outlet stream was quenched with dimethyl acetylenedicarboxylate 42 to assist in the quantification. Additionally, the diazoalkanes were demonstrated to react readily in esterifications, ring closures, and cycloadditions.

    3.3.5. Organic Azides

    Organic azides represent another class of molecules readily prepared in situ. The Jamison group has developed a continuous flow synthesis of rufinamide 43 starting from readily available and stable starting materials.(55) In this synthesis, two unstable starting materials (2,6-difluorobenzyl azide 44 and propiolamide 45) are generated and consumed immediately in flow to afford rufinamide 43 in high yield (Scheme 29). Organic azide 44 is generated in situ by reaction of an aryl bromide with sodium azide. Using a copper reactor coil, the azide and alkyne are coupled via click chemistry, in a similar fashion previously described on a library setting.(56) This procedure was demonstrated to generate >200 mg/h of rufinamide 43.
    Chemists at AstraZeneca have relied on flow chemistry for the synthesis and coupling of methyl azidoacetate 46.(57) In this route, the isolation of the hazardous azide 46 was avoided by its subsequent reaction with 3-methylbut-1-yne 47, affording the 1,2,3-triazole product 48. Using in-line FT-IR, the reactions could readily be optimized and methyl azidoacetate 46 generation and consumption could be easily monitored. A continuous manufacturing process was later developed, which was capable of synthesizing 770 g of triazole 48 from a 19.5 h synthesis (Scheme 30).

    3.3.6. Alkyl and Aryl Zinc Formation

    Alcazar and co-workers have described novel techniques for synthesizing alkyl zinc substrates that can be used in situ or stored for short periods. In this procedure, solutions of alkyl halides are passed through packed beds of solid zinc granules, resulting in solutions of alkyl zinc reagents 49 that exit the reactor.(58,59) The outlet stream can subsequently be used in Reformatsky reactions or Negishi couplings (Scheme 31) and has been demonstrated that substrates can be run on 25 mmol scale and stored for future use. The process simplifies methods for the generation of alkylzincs by removing necessary filtration steps and providing better temperature control of the zinc insertion.
    Using flow chemistry has also enabled the synthesis of Î±-trifluoromethyl oxiranyl zincate.(60) The zinc species is generated by deprotonation of the trifluoromethyl epoxide 50 with nBuLi, followed by mixing with a stream of ZnCl2 at â50 Â°C. The flow reaction is subsequently collected in a round-bottom flask where a batch Negishi coupling ensues in high yield (Scheme 32). A truncated synthesis of HSD-016 51, a drug candidate for treatment of diabetes, was carried out using this procedure. The Negishi/reduction synthetic route described in Scheme 33 takes the previously reported synthesis from five steps down to two, with a >30% increase in yield. For this reaction, it is imperative to use small bore tubing for improved mixing. The overall simplicity of this setup can be seen in Figure 7.
    Buchwald and co-workers have reported a separate Negishi protocol that can be used to synthesize arylâaryl bonds using in situ generated aryl zincs.(61) In this procedure, aryl fluorides are ortho-lithiated with nBuLi and quenched with ZnCl2 to yield aryl zinc substrates, which are coupled in situ with aryl halides (Scheme 34). Similarly, trifluoromethyl arenes and pyridyl fluorides (using LDA as metalating agent) underwent a similar transformation in modest to excellent yields.

    3.4. Gas-Mediated Flow Chemistry

    Gas-mediated reactions in flow, specifically hydrogenations, have been an industry mainstay for the past few decades due to increased safety profiles associated with running the reactions.(62) One of the first commercially available flow chemistry reactors was the H-Cube by ThalesNano, a benchtop flow hydrogenation unit. In present day, gas-mediated reactions have been developed far beyond the laboratory scale and are being used in manufacturing settings, in some cases generating >2 MT of product in 24 days.(63) Apart from flow hydrogenations,(64â66) a number of other gas-mediated reactions have been reported, including oxidations,(67â69) carbonylations,(70) fluorinations,(71) and propyne gas-mediated Sonogashira couplings.(72) In a majority of cases, the introduction of a gas into a flow reaction is carried out using a gas cylinder and a mass-flow controller. However, alternative technologies exist that can be used to safely run gas-mediated reactions, in many cases using potentially hazardous reagents.

    3.4.1. Tube-in-Tube Reactors

    The use of tube-in-tube reactors has become a common technique used to introduce gases into a flow reactor. This system consists of inner gas-permeable tube (commonly made of Teflon AF-2400) housed within a larger tube. Gases can be supplied via conventional or reverse methods (inside or outside of the AF-2400 tubing, respectively, Figure 8). Teflon AF-2400 is a highly permeable material for gases but not liquids, thus enabling gases to diffuse through the tubing into the organic reaction stream. The use of gas cylinders in conjunction with tube-in-tube reactors has been recently reviewed and shows the application of this technique using gases such as ozone, hydrogen, ammonia, carbon monoxide, carbon dioxide, and syngas.(73) Tube-in-tube reactors also enable reactive gases such as diazomethane to be generated on demand and used in the synthesis of novel intermediates.
    Diazomethane (CH2N2) is a highly versatile reagent in organic synthesis; however its use is limited due to the required specialty glassware and safety concerns associated with its use.(74) The Kappe group has reported a continuous flow synthesis of diazomethane using a tube-in-tube reactor, in which diazomethane is generated in situ by the reaction of Diazald 52 and KOH.(75) Diazomethane generated by this reaction is passed through the inner tube of the tube-in-tube reactor, and gas bubbles permeate through the tubing into the outer reagent stream (Figure 9). By variation of the substrate present in the outer stream of the tube-in-tube reactor, products such as cyclopropanes, methyl esters, and Î±-diazocarbonyls can be synthesized in high yield (Figure 10). This process was further elaborated to synthesize Î±-chloroketones 53 in gram quantities in a three-step continuous flow process (Scheme 35).(76) Following the mixed anhydride formation of an amino acid 54, diazomethane was introduced into the reaction stream via a tube-in-tube reactor to form a diazoketone. Upon exiting the tube-in-tube reactor, the reagent stream is mixed with HCl in diethyl ether, forming an Î±-chloromethyl ketone 53 in excellent yield.
    Koolman and co-workers further expanded upon this tube-in-tube reactor by developing an automated diazomethane platform (DRIFT, diazomethane reactor in flow technology) that can be used for library generation or reaction scale-up (Figure 11).(77) As opposed to reactions being run in the outer tube of the tube-in-tube reactor, DRIFT prepares an anhydrous solution of diazomethane in THF, which is mixed with a reagent stream to afford the desired products. It was noted that when reagent streams pass over the tube-in-tube reactor, palladium nanoparticle build-up over time was observed on the AF-2400 tubing, leading to inconsistent results.
    With DRIFT running in library production mode, a series of 15 arylcyclopropyl boronates were synthesized in modest yield. Using the automated scale-up mode, up to 190 mg/h of substrate could also be obtained (Scheme 36). Within AbbVie, DRIFT has been applied to drug discovery in the context of building block and intermediate synthesis.
    Dallinger and Kappe have described a simplified hybrid batch/flow procedure for facile scaling of diazomethane reactions.(78,79) Instead of running substrates through the outer tube of the tube-in-tube reactor, the authors describe a system where the gas-permeable AF-2400 tubing is submerged in a reaction vessel (Figure 12). Similar to flow, a number of different diazomethane-mediated reactions were performed using this system. Scale-up was achieved by adding more AF-2400 tubing to the reactor as opposed to increasing the diameter of the tubing, permitting >40 g of methyl benzoate to be prepared during an 8 h run.
    Kappe and co-workers have also demonstrated the use of trifluoromethyl diazomethane using a tube-in-tube reactor.(80) In this case, the diazo compound was synthesized by treatment of trifluoroethylamine with sodium nitrite. In a telescoped process, trifluoromethyl diazomethane was generated on demand and condensed with aldehydes in flow, resulting in the final diazo product 55 modest to excellent yield (Scheme 37). This synthesis provides another example of gases that can be generated on-demand using a tube-in-tube reactor.

    3.5. Flow Photochemistry

    Photochemistry has had a remarkable resurgence over the past few years, in part because of flow chemistry. While traditional photochemical reactors have been well-established for decades, issues of scalability and nonuniform irradiation rendered this technology unfavorable, specifically on scale. Indeed, most recent advances in photochemistry have involved the use of flow reactors.(81â84) In comparison to a photochemical immersion well, flow reactors have short path lengths (i.e., tubing diameter) which can greatly enhance the irradiation of the reaction mixture with light (both UV and visible). For this reason, reactions traditionally run in batch photochemical reactors can be carried out in flow, providing high yields in shorter reaction times.
    Flow photochemical reactors exist in a wide variety of states (Figure 13). Reactors can be set up using traditional photochemical equipment wrapped in transparent tubing. Alternatively, AbbVie has described the LOPHTOR (flow-through photochemical micoreactor), a custom-built flow reactor with microchannels etched into a stainless steel plate, which is irradiated with UV light from a medium-pressure mercury lamp.(85) Recently, add-ons to commercial flow systems have been marketed bringing rise to this technology once more. Using reactor designs such as these has made photochemistry pharmaceutically relevant once again.

    3.5.1. Rearrangements

    The Baxendale group has described the use of a flow photoreactor to synthesize ibuprofen in a continuous flow process via a photo-Favorskii rearrangement of isobutyl chloropropiophenone 56 (Scheme 38A).(86) This two-step photochemical synthesis of ibuprofen 57 has a maximum throughput of 5.7 mmol/h, and the final product can be isolated as a white solid by simple acid/base extraction and trituration from hexanes.
    Scientists at Vertex have reported a continuous flow method for the synthesis of lactams by the light-catalyzed rearrangement of spiro-oxaziridines (Scheme 38B).(87) The reported setup (similar to what Figure 13A) gives yields that are the same or higher than the batch reaction with shorter reaction times. This photolysis reaction was done on up to 80 g of material 58 with a moderate yield (51%, 99% based on RSM) en route to a desired chiral amine 59.
    A number of flow photochemistry examples have been reported using LEDs as opposed to UV light. Having established a batch process for the Smiles rearrangement of 60 enabled by the use of visible light, the Stephenson group has developed a complementary flow chemistry process capable of scaling reactions beyond 100 g.(88) Reactions were carried out in a microchip that was placed on top of an LED light source. Using a residence time of 10 min, alcohol 61 was obtained in a 65% yield on 5.4 g scale (Scheme 38C).

    3.5.2. Continuous Flow Synthesis of Artemisinin

    Seeberger et al. have reported the continuous flow synthesis of artemisinin 62 (Scheme 39).(89) A singlet-oxygen-induced ene reaction and the addition of triplet oxygen initiate the endoperoxide incorporation that is necessary to make artemisinin. This endoperoxide 63 was prepared by the introduction of dihydroartemisinic acid 64, oxygen gas, and photosensitizer to a flow photochemical reactor (450W medium-pressure mercury lamp) with a 2 min residence time. The outlet stream was treated with TFA at converting the endoperoxide 63 to artemisinin 64 with a 39% isolated yield after column chromatography (Scheme 39). The continuous flow setup allows for large-scale production with the possibility of producing 200 g/day. Furthermore, the flow process described therein shows greater promise of scalability in comparison to other reported batch processes, as well as more efficient use of singlet oxygen.

    3.5.3. Cyclizations

    Photochemical cyclizations are historical transformations that are once again gaining utility due to improved reactivity in flow. For instance, at AbbVie a photochemical cyclization was carried out on gram scale, providing a key intermediate 65 for a 5HT2C program (Scheme 40A).(90) Similarly, tricyclic scaffolds have been prepared by [2 + 2] photocycloaddition using a continuous flow setup.(91) Small scale runs were transitioned to a large-scale flow photoreactor, where 10â20 g of starting material could be processed in a 9.5â14.6 h period, with isolated yields similar to the small scale runs (Scheme 40B).
    The photochemical transformation of pyrroles into tricyclic aziridines via a [2 + 2] cycloaddition and rearrangement has been reported by the Booker-Milburn group (Scheme 41A and Scheme 41B).(92) An electron-withdrawing group at the C2 position is necessary for the reaction to occur. Otherwise, the reaction was very tolerant of substitution around the pyrrole ring. The scale-up of two examples showed similar isolated yields to the batch reaction. This method was used in a subsequent paper for the total synthesis of (+)-demethoxyerythratidinone 66 (Scheme 41C).(93)
    Starting from the commercially available d-isosorbide 67, a short, scalable synthesis of (+)-goniofufurone was undertaken by the Booker-Milburn group, utilizing a photochemical PaternÃ²âBÃ¼chi reaction to reach a key intermediate 68 (Scheme 42).(94) While the photochemical reaction in batch provided high yields, the reaction was slow and run very dilute. Therefore, scale-up of the batch reaction was deemed impractical. Using a three-layer FEP flow reactor (tubing wrapped around immersion well such that light irradiates three layers of tubing) with a 400 W medium-pressure mercury lamp over 83 h, 42 g of intermediate 68 (2:1 mixture of regioisomers) was obtained in a 97% isolated yield. After four more steps, (+)-goniofufurone was isolated and the structure was confirmed by X-ray crystallography.
    The Jamison group has reported a three-step continuous synthesis of a quinoxalines 69. The synthesis is enabled by the in situ formation of isocyanide intermediates, which undergo a photochemical cyclization with phenyliodine(III) dicarboxylates.(95) With a total residence time of 14.6 min for a three-step process, the product was obtained in 47% isolated yield. In this flow setup, the flow reactor was coiled around compact fluorescent light bulb to facilitate the cyclization (Scheme 43).

    3.5.4. Total Synthesis in Flow

    The Stephenson group has demonstrated the application of visible-light photochemistry in the synthesis of a key intermediate to (â)-pseudotabersonine (Scheme 44).(96) Cataranthanine 70 was irradiated in the presence of an iridium catalyst and trimethylsilyl cyanide (TMSCN), generating the ring-opened material 71 in 96% yield with a 2 min residence time. This flow procedure improves the scalability of the process and has an improved safety profile due to its ability to safely control the generation of toxic HCN. A similar photocatalytic fragmentation in flow was also described to prepare other complex intermediates.

    3.5.5. Homologation

    By combining the aforementioned tube-in-tube technology with flow photochemistry, Kappe and co-workers have described the preparation of Î²-amino acids 72 from Î±-amino acids using the ArndtâEistert homologation (Scheme 45). In this setup, the photochemical reactor was achieved by a UV-CFL light source and a PFA coiled reactor.(97) A diazocarbonyl intermediate is prepared using tube-in-tube technology which is converted to a carboxylic acid using a photochemically enabled Wolff rearrangement. The four-step continuous process gives the desired products in low to moderate yields without erosion of the enantiopurity of the starting materials.

    3.5.6. Halogenations

    The Kappe group has developed an efficient benzylic bromination method using only 1.05 equiv of N-bromosuccinimide (NBS) in a continuous-flow process utilizing transparent fluorinated ethylene polymer (FEP) tubing and a compact fluorescent lamp (CFL) to initiate the radical reaction (Figure 14).(98,99) Good to excellent yields were achieved for simple aromatic systems with up to 30 mmol of compound being processed an hour. The group has also extended this method to benzylic fluorinations by switching to Selectfluor, 5 mol % xanthone as a photoorganocatalyst, and black light (Scheme 46A). In this case, some substrates required heating to 60 Â°C to achieve good yields.
    A photochemical bromination has been carried out on gram-scale to synthesize halide 73 in support of medicinal chemistry programs using the LOPHTOR (Scheme 46B). Similarly, the benzylic bromination of a rosuvastatin precursor 74 using N-bromosuccinimide (NBS) and a 150 W medium-pressure Hg lamp has been reported by the Äasar group (Scheme 46C).(100) In this synthesis of halide 75, the flow reaction was more efficient, scalable and gave less undesired bromination and photochemical degradation than the batch process.

    3.5.7. Oxidation

    The NoÃ«l group has reported a mild and chemoselective oxidation of sp3 CâH bonds using tetrabutylammonium decatungstate (TBADT) as a photocatalyst and oxygen as the oxidant (Scheme 47).(101) A continuous flow setup able to safely handle oxygen and 365 nm LEDs was utilized (Figure 15). Many activated and unactivated aliphatic examples were shown in the substrate scope, including examples of late-stage functionalization.

    3.5.8. Deoxygenation

    The Stephenson group has reported a mild, one-pot deoxygenation of primary and secondary alcohols with good functional group tolerance (Scheme 48).(102) The reaction proceeds through an alkyl iodide intermediate by a GareggâSamuelsson reaction, which is deiodinated with an iridium catalyst under visible light irradiation. The reported procedure has >100Ã the throughput in flow than in batch due to improvements of irradiation of reactions in flow.

    3.5.9. CarbonâSulfur Bond Formation

    A mild, one-pot StadlerâZiegler reaction to form arylsulfides has been developed by the NoÃ«l group.(103) Using visible light and a photoredox catalyst, aryl amines and aryl or alkyl thiols were coupled to form arylsulfides in moderate to good yields (Scheme 49). The one-pot nature of the method makes the process safer by eliminating the usual step of diazonium salt isolation and minimizing formation of diazosulfides. Performing the reaction in microreactors also gave rate accelerations, compared to the batch reaction, due to better irradiation of the solution. Up to 13.2 mmol/h (15 s residence time) was synthesized using their continuous flow setup.

    3.5.10. Trifluoromethylation

    NoÃ«l and co-workers have reported the trifluoromethylation and perfluoroalkylation of five-membered heterocycles (Scheme 50).(104) Using Ru(bpy)32+ and TMEDA, pyrroles and indoles were perfluoroalkylated in moderate to excellent yields with 10â20 min residence times. A wider set of five-membered heterocycles were trifluoromethylated using gaseous CF3I in good to excellent yields. The segmented gasâliquid flow reaction was performed by mixing the liquid and gas in a T-shaped micromixer before being irradiated. The flow reaction, which was complete in 8â16 min, gave a great acceleration in the rate of the reaction from the 12â72 h necessary for completion of the batch reaction.
    A two-step continuous flow protocol for the Î±-trifluoromethylation of ketones has been demonstrated by the Kappe group (Scheme 51).(105) In the first step, the ketone reacts with trimethylsilyl triflate (TMSOTf) and diisopropylethylamine to generate the silyl enol ether in situ. Using eosin Y as a photoredox catalyst and visible light, triflyl chloride, a CF3 radical source, reacts with the in situ generated silyl enol ether 76 to efficiently generate the trifluoromethylated products 77. The flow process gave lower amounts of side products and allowed for decreasing the amount of catalyst to below 1 mol %. In addition, the entire process is complete within 20 min, enabling the rapid generation of an array of trifluoromethylated compounds.
    When used with pyridine-N-oxide, blue LEDs, and a ruthenium photoredox catalyst, trifluoroacetic anhydride was able to be utilized as an inexpensive CF3 source to trifluoromethylate aromatic and heteroaromatic compounds.(106,107) The reaction was shown to be scalable up to 100 g, and when translated to a flow process, the yields were improved, albeit with lower selectivity (Scheme 52). In a subsequent report, the Stephenson group was able to scale out the reaction of 1-(tert-butyl) 2-methyl 1H-pyrrole-1,2-dicarboxylate 78 to produce 0.95 kg of 79 per day in a 50% isolated yield. The scaled up flow reactor contained PFA tubing (total volume of 150 mL) that was placed around three blue LED lamps (Figure 16). The entire setup was submerged in a cooling bath housed within a garbage bin, which was also used to contain the light during production.

    3.5.11. CarbonâCarbon Bond Formation

    Chemists at Novartis have employed flow photochemical methods to synthesize bicyclo[1.1.1]pentane analogs in efforts to study para-phenyl bioisosteres. Using a medium-pressure mercury lamp flow photochemical setup, propellane 80 could be inserted into N-Boc-3-iodoalanine methyl ester 81 in modest yield (Scheme 53).(108) Over 6 g of final bicycle[1.1.1]pentane 82 was generated from this procedure.
    Using UV photolysis in flow, unstable diazo compounds were synthesized in situ from oxadiazolines and coupled with an array of commercially available boronic acids.(109) This methodology was applied in the synthesis of numerous sp2âsp3 bonds, generating an intermediate boronate 83 that can be used in a number of subsequent transformations without isolation (protonation, hydroxylation, or pincaol borane formation, Scheme 54A). The authors further expanded upon this methodology to synthesize baclofen 84, in a three-step photochemically enabled synthesis (Scheme 54B).
    Utilizing dual iridium and nickel catalysis, the Ley group has developed a continuous flow protocol for sp2âsp3 cross coupling by photoredox activation of boronic esters.(110) By using the boronic esters, the solubility issues usually seen with potassium trifluoroborate salts are avoided, which makes the process amenable to flow conditions. The formation of an activated complex of the boronic ester and a Lewis basic additive is necessary for the reaction to occur. This method was expanded to include the coupling of heteroaromatic nitriles and boronic esters (Scheme 55).
    The coupling of aryl bromides and alkylpotassium trifluoroborates using nickel and iridium photoredox catalysis in a continuous flow format has been reported by the Boyd group to good yields that are achieved with a broad substrate scope.(111) After development of a soluble system for this coupling, a small library of compounds could be synthesized. Scale-up of this procedure was also demonstrated, generating 81 mg/h of compound (Scheme 56).
    In a follow-up manuscript, scientists at Vertex have shown the photoredox cross-coupling of aryl halides with primary and secondary alkyl potassium trifluoroborates as well as silicate reagents.(112) The use of the silicate reagents permits the synthesis of a series of linear analogs otherwise not achievable using trifluoroborate salts (Scheme 57). Additionally, the flow procedure oftentimes had a higher yield in flow in comparison to batch.

    3.6. Electrochemistry

    Over the past few years, the number of publications highlighting organic reactions mediated by electrochemistry has greatly increased. By application of an electrical potential, electrons can be added/removed from a reaction mixture, thus facilitating the overall transformation.(113â115) With the flow chemistry market developing tools to enable high temperature chemistry, cryogenic reactions, and photochemistry, it comes as little surprise that companies have started production of electrochemical reactors. To facilitate electron transfer between electrodes, ideally these surfaces would be in close proximity to each other, with the reaction mixture passing between. In essence, the high surface-area-to-volume ratios of a flow reactor make electrochemistry an area of interest, potentially providing high scalability and cleaner transformations than comparative batch processed.
    Table 2. Flow Chemistry Applications and Solutions
