    3.6.1. Oxidation

    In order to isolate and fully characterize oxidative metabolites of commercial drugs, continuous flow electrolysis was used to synthesize the metabolites on 10â100 mg scale (Scheme 58).(116) A commercially available microfluidic electrochemical cell from Syrris was used to allow for high-throughput on the desired scale while simulating CYP450 oxidation (Figure 17). Five commercial drugs, diclofenac, tolbutamide, primidone, albendazole, and chlorpromazine, which are known to undergo various types of oxidation, were used to test the cell.
    The synthesis of the indole alkaloid nazlinine 85 and relatives by flow electrochemistry has been reported by Ley et al.(117) Using a continuous flow electrochemical cell and a carbon anode allowed for the use of only 20 mol % of the electrolyte in the Shono oxidation of cyclic amines while still retaining high yields and product purity. The output solution from the electrochemical cell underwent a solvent switch and filtration before a PictetâSpengler cyclization was performed in microwave to form the tricycle that makes up the core structure of nazlinine (Scheme 59).
    A modular flow cell with an undivided or divided mode and which allows for changing the electrode materials, electrode gap, and flow easily was developed by the Waldvogel group.(118) To demonstrate its abilities in undivided mode, the group was able to make a nitrile 86 from an aldoxime 87 using an oxidationâreduction sequence shown in Scheme 60 without over-reduction to the monochloro compound, a common byproduct seen in batch reactions. To demonstrate benefits of the divided mode, the nitrile oxide 88 was prevented from being reduced at the cathode to the nitrile in order to make an important precursor to dicloxacillin 89, a penicillin derivative, via a 1,3-dipolar cycloaddition with methyl acetoacetate 90 (Scheme 61). For this work, all electrochemical equipment was custom-built.
    The Brown group, along with their GlaxoSmithKline (GSK) collaborators, has described an N-heterocyclic carbene (NHC)-mediated oxidative esterification (Scheme 62).(119,120) By pumping a solution of the aldehyde 90, MeOH, and the NHC salt in DMSO/THF into a T-mixer with a solution of DBU in THF and passing the resulting solution through the electrolysis cell with a current of 850 mA, the desired ester 91 was formed. Using an undivided microfluidic electrolysis cell, up to 4.3 g/h was able to be produced with very good yields. The conditions were also demonstrated to be effective on a variety of aryl and heteroaryl aldehydes and with several alkyl alcohols. Using a similar setup with primary amines instead of alcohols, aldehydes were transformed into amides with good yields. Optimization of the mixing protocol prevented formation of an imine, which would decrease the yield of the desired amide.
    Flow photochemistry and electrochemistry have been combined into a singled process in the electrocatalytic depolymerization of lignin, a polymeric material that makes up the cell walls of plants (Figure 18).(121) Unlike typical harsh lignin degradation conditions, the two-step, one-pot, batch to flow process proceeds at ambient temperature. By linking together an electrocatalytic oxidation using N-hydroxyphthalimide (NHPI) and 2,6-lutidine with an iridium photocatalytic cleavage, native lignin and lignin-type dimers were fragmented.
    The Green group, in collaboration with Cambridge Reactor Design Ltd., has demonstrated the power of their large microflow electrolysis cell for the multigram scale methoxylation of N-formylpyrrolidine, a common model system (Figure 19).(122) In a single pass, there is almost complete conversion of the starting material with excellent selectivity. With this system, product can be formed at a rate of >20 g/h.

    3.6.2. Cyclization

    An electrochemical flow microreactor that diminishes or eliminates the need for electrolytes was developed by Wirth et al. and used to make isoindolinones (Figure 20).(123) To optimize reactions, an in-line mass spectrometer was incorporated at the outlet of the flow reactor. Relative abundancies of product and starting material were monitored upon variation of the applied electrical charge. Two separate reaction cascades were demonstrated in the synthesis of isoindolinones. In the first sequence, the TEMPO moiety incorporated following the cyclization was eliminated thermally to give the alkene species (Scheme 63A). An alternative method was also demonstrated where the TEMPO moiety was reduced via acetic acid and zinc, providing the final hydroxyl compound (Scheme 63B).

    3.6.3. Dehalogenation

    The Waldvogel group and collaborators at Novartis have developed the dehalogenation of a spirocyclopropane proline derivative 92, a key intermediate for the synthesis of Ledipasvir, a NS5A inhibitor, using a flow electrolysis cell with a leaded bronze cathode.(124) Other routes to make this proline derivative 93, such as a Birch reduction or hydrogenolysis, gave moderate yields. The Birch reduction suffered from racemization and ring opening of the cyclopropane. Hydrogenolysis using Pd/C also gave ring opened byproducts. The reported electrochemical dehalogenation gave the desired product with excellent yield and purity (Scheme 64).

    3.6.4. CarbonâCarbon Bond Formation

    Researchers at Snapdragon and MIT have collaborated to develop a continuous flow electrochemical cross-coupling using N-hydroxyphthalamide esters and aryl iodides.(125) Having optimized the decarboxylative cross-coupling using a batch electrochemical setup, the methodology was transitioned to batch using a C-flow electrochemical reactor (Scheme 65).(126) Complete conversion of the activated ester 94 to the final product 95 was observed using a 8.3 min residence time. This flow synthesis also demonstrates the potential of scaling electrochemical reactions.

    4. Continuous Flow Synthesis of API

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    Flow chemistry enables the rapid synthesis of API by combining multiple synthesis and purification steps into one continuous process. The first multistep continuous flow synthesis was reported by the Ley group in 2006, when they reported a seven-step route to the natural product oxomaritidine using a series of immobilized reagents and scavengers to facilitate the overall process.(127) The use of immobilized reagents and scavengers permits essentially pure product to be transitioned from one reaction step to the next. However, with this approach comes somewhat limited scalability due to depletion of reagents or saturation of scavengers. If multistep reaction sequences are completely solution phase, overall synthetic routes may need to be reworked compared to a stepwise process to ensure that reaction steps are not fouled by upstream processes. Over the past number of years, there have been significant advances in the field of continuous flow synthesis, assisting with intermediate purification, phase separation and even to final API formulation. Syntheses such as these have been shown to be highly efficient with many advantages over stepwise batch processes. The combination of these new technologies has also enabled larger quantities of material to be synthesized in flow, making this technology more synthetically tractable for use in pharmaceutical settings.
    In the flow synthesis of imatinib, the Ley group expanded upon the scavenger enabled multistep synthesis of oxomaritidine and developed a process amenable to analog synthesis.(128) Novel techniques for the inline solvent removal step are demonstrated during this process, enabling the switch between dichloromethane and dimethylformamide. Following peptide coupling, the intermediate 96 is captured on an immobilized sulfonic acid resin, to wash of unreacted materials and provide means for changing the solvent from DMF to 2:1 dioxane/tBuOH. Upon treatment of the sulfonic acid resin DBU, the intermediate aryl halide 96 is released and coupled to an aryl amine via a BuchwaldâHartwig amination. In total, nine separate analogs of imatinib could be synthesized on 23â35 mg scale (Scheme 66).
    The Ley group has reported a five-step telescoped synthesis of (E/Z)-tamoxifen 97 (Scheme 67).(129) The authors credit the use of an advanced peristaltic pump to enable the key lithiation step by pumping the organometallic through the pump directly from the commercial bottle. In the telescoped synthesis, lithiumâhalogen exchange of the aryl bromide 98 was performed by mixing with nBuLi at â50 Â°C. It is important to note that precooling both solutions was necessary. The outflow from this reactor containing the aryllithium was mixed with the precooled ketone 99. After mixing at â50 Â°C for 0.16 min, the temperature of the outflow solution was raised to 30 Â°C for 1.96 min before mixing with TFAA at ambient temperature. Finally, mixing the solution with Et3N at 100 Â°C to facilitate elimination gave the desired product 97 in 84% isolated yield after a short silica plug. This continuous synthesis telescoped four reactions to generate >12 g of material in an 80 min process and demonstrates the feasibility of performing a continuous flow synthesis completely in solution phase.
    With the development of a continuous flow synthesis of an atazanavir intermediate 100, the research groups of Kappe and de Souza have reported a three-step process highlighting how phase separation technology can be used in flow to enable mulit-step syntheses (Scheme 68).(130) The process involves a high-temperature Suzuki coupling to provide a biaryl aldehyde 101 intermediate, which was phase separated in batch before being carried on to the next reaction step. The resulting aldehyde was converted to a Boc-protected hydrazine 102, which was washed with aqueous potassium carbonate prior to being reduced via flow hydrogenolysis in the H-Cube. In order to remove water from the reaction prior to injection in the H-Cube, the reaction mixture passes through a membrane phase separator (FLLEX separator from Syrris) where the aqueous waste is separated from the organic reaction stream.
    The Jamison group has reported a continuous-flow process to generate ibuprofen 57 (Scheme 69).(131) The overall process consists of three reaction steps, one aqueous workup, and one liquidâliquid separation. An 83% isolated yield of the sodium salt of ibuprofen 103 was achieved with a total residence time of 3 min. The system had a production rate of 8.09 g/h. Phase separation technology that was used in this synthesis was further employed in the continuous flow synthesis of atropine, where three phase-separators and multiple pH changes were carried out in order to isolate pure product.(132)
    Having the flexibility to integrate multiple chemical reactors with purification/phase separation has subsequently assisted in generating pharmaceuticals on demand (Figure 21).(133) Research groups at MIT have collaborated in a project aimed at generating continuous routes to APIs from synthesis to formulation. This integrated platform is refrigerator-sized and is capable of generating hundreds to thousands of individual doses of API during a 24 h period (Figure 22). Within the platform are housed reactor coils for heating/cooling, packed-bed cartridges, membrane separators, etc. that can be used/bypassed depending on the synthetic route. This plug-and-play capability enabled four specific APIs (diphenhydramine hydrochloride, lidocaine hydrochloride, diazepam, and fluoxetine hydrochloride) to be synthesized using the platform. Further modifications were made to include formulation units, as well as a new evaporation unit.(134) This highly configurable approach was subsequently applied to a new series of APIs, generating up to 9600 doses of API per day for high-value medicines such as ciprofloxacin.
    While the aforementioned on-demand synthesis for ciprofloxacin 104 started from an advanced intermediate, the Jamison and Jensen groups have described a total synthesis using a five-step, continuous flow process (Scheme 70).(135) Without requiring any intermediate purification or phase separation steps, the entire process is complete within 9 min, and pure product can be isolated by simple pH adjustment and crystallization. Worth noting however is that some reaction steps had to be reworked to facilitate this continuous synthesis. Specifically, following the conjugate addition to the Michael acceptor 105, the dimethylamine byproduct was acylated with acetyl chloride, forming dimethylacetamide (DMA), in order to prevent the fouling of the subsequent SNAr step.
    A continuous flow synthesis for dolutegravir 106 has also been published.(136) To synthesize this complex molecule, the seven step synthesis had to be broken down into three separate flow operations (Scheme 71). Issues with precipitation during the full synthetic route prevented the sequence from being completely telescoped and limited its long-term stability. Nonetheless, the described synthesis reduces the overall step count in the synthesis of dolutegravir and also enables two additional APIs to be generated by varying the benzyl amine and amino alcohols (circled in reaction scheme).
    The Jamison group has extended the synthesis of diazo compounds in flow to an assembly line platform for the synthesis of pyrazoles and pyrazolines (Scheme 72A).(137) Either di- or trifluoroethylamine is treated with tBuONO and reacted with a series of alkenes and alkynes, generating a large library of heterocycles in modest to excellent yield. The synthesis for these heterocycles was further telescoped into a series of transformations, ultimately enabling the synthesis of AS-136A inhibitor in a four-step continuous flow process (Scheme 72B). Additional transformations such as alkylations, amidations, and arylations can all be telescoped into the flow synthesis, enabling the rapid generation of structurally diverse compounds.
    Continuous flow synthesis has been reported on an industrial scale by researchers at Eli Lilly (Scheme 73).(138) In the development of a continuous route to prexasertib monolactate monohydrate, a number of the aforementioned techniques were applied to assist with synthesizing almost 3 kg of API per day. Following a heterocycle formation with a nitrile 110 and hydrazine, the reaction is continuously extracted with a carbonate solution, toluene, and water. The resultant solution of aminopyrazole 111 in methanol/toluene/water is diluted with DMSO and transferred to a 20 L rotary evaporator to remove volatiles. This process is capable of generating 3.1 kg of material per day, and the DMSO stock solution can subsequently be used in further reaction steps or stored for >60 days.
    The synthesis of prexasertib is completed by the SNAr between the aminopyrazole intermediate 111 solution with a chloropyrazine 112 at 80 Â°C. Following continuous crystallization and filtration steps, the filter cake was dissolved in formic acid and transitioned to a plug flow reactor to facilitate the Boc-deprotection. Water was added to the reaction stream and the resulting solution of prexasertib as the formic acid salt 113 was transitioned to a batch process, completing the formulation of the API as the lactate salt.

    5. Automated Flow Synthesis Platforms

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    An additional benefit of flow reactors is their ability to be automated and readily integrated with additional laboratory equipment. Automated flow reactors can enable high-throughput chemical synthesis as well as reaction screening. These platforms can be used across the pharmaceutical industry to assist in the discovery of new therapeutics, as well as shorten the development time of APIs.

    5.1. Segmented Flow: Fluorous Spacers

    Segmented flow is a process by which multiple reactions can be run in rapid succession within a flow reactor. Technology such as this can be used for the generation or chemical libraries or for the rapid analysis of multiple reaction conditions. Segments can be separated by use a fluorous (such as perfluorodecalin or perfluoromethyldecalin) or gaseous spacer, which help maintain each reaction as a discrete entity within the overall flow path of the reactor (Figure 23). Use of a spacer also prevents cross-contamination between reactions.
    One example of an automated flow synthesizer is the Conjure by Accendo. The Fluid Prep module of the Conjure is a liquid handler consisting of four separate syringe drives, which are responsible for the sampling and mixing components of the reaction. These reagents are mixed at ambient temperature and pressure prior to being injected into the heated reactor module (Figure 23).(139) In the first publication describing the Conjure, a library of 1,2,3-triazoles was synthesized using segmented flow.(56) For the triazole library, a one-pot âclickâ chemistry methodology was developed where low-molecular weight azides were generated in situ from alkyl halides and sodium azide and coupled to alkynes using a copper reactor coil (Scheme 74). This manuscript led to future work by Lange, in which the Conjure was used in the preparation of 3-aminoindolizine libraries(140) and later applied to a multistep protocol (Scheme 75).(141) In all of these cases, the use of automation and segmented flow enabled a large number of compounds to be synthesized in a very efficient manner.
    At AbbVie the Conjure was developed further into the SWIFT platform (synthesis with integrated flow technology) to enable a fully integrated library synthesis and purification platform.(142,143) Synthesis on the SWIFT platform is carried out in segmented flow using the Conjure flow reactor, and purification is carried out by integration with a preparative HPLC/MS (Figure 24). Upon exiting the flow reactor, segments are captured in an injection loop and directly purified. This setup enables chemical libraries to be synthesized at a rate of six pure compounds per hour, ranging between 10 and 20 mg of product per reaction. The use of this integrated system at AbbVie has significantly reduced cycle times in discovery and has been used in a number of early stage projects to push projects toward candidate nomination.(144)
    Chemistry run on the SWIFT platform is dictated by solubility of starting materials. Reactions are typically run with a 10 min residence time at elevated temperatures in order to optimize throughput. Aside from solubility, another main limitation of the SWIFT system is solvent compatibility. Specifically, reactions run on SWIFT system are limited to solvents that are water-miscible and that are compatible with the HPLC column. For this reason, the most commonly used solvents are DMA, DMSO, MeOH, THF, and MeCN. Lastly, transition metal catalyzed reactions are typically worked up and purified off-line to prevent guard and HPLC column blockages. As the platform is a high throughput synthesis tool, reactions with a wide variety of available monomers are preferred (acylations, reductive amination, sulfonylation, alkylation, etc.). High-temperature-mediated heterocycle formations have been exemplified starting from carboxylic acids (Scheme 76).(145) In the synthesis of 1,2,4-oxadiazoles, carboxylic acids are incubated with HATU and then mixed with hydroxyamidines to form activated esters. Subsequent heating of the reaction mixture to 175 Â°C closes the heterocycle in modest to excellent yield. The methodology was further applied to the synthesis of various 1,2,4-triazoles.

    5.2. Segmented Flow: Oscillating Droplets

    An alternative methodology for running segmented flow reactions is the use of oscillating droplets separated by a gaseous spacer.(146,147) The Jensen group has pioneered this field and have developed automated platforms for synthesizing compound libraries and optimizing reactions (Figure 25). Similar to the Conjure system, reaction droplets are prepared using a liquid handler and mixed prior to being injected into the reactor unit. Upon being loaded into the reactor unit, a syringe pump is used to control the motion of the droplet in the reactor. At the end of the reaction, the droplet can be directly sampled and monitored by HPLC/MS/ELSD. Additionally, products can be isolated from the purification run via mass-triggered fraction collection.
    Using this procedure, a 36-member library consisting of four separate reaction types was carried out (Scheme 77). All reactions were complete in <20 min and 35/36 reaction proceeded in modest to excellent conversion (one reaction failed). A Suzuki coupling was also validated using this platform in which a biphasic reaction was mixed efficiently via oscillation of the reaction droplet (Figure 26).

    5.3. Automated Flow: Peptide Synthesis

    The Pentelute group at MIT has developed an automated flow peptide synthesis platform that relies on the a combination of flow chemistry and solid-phase synthesis.(148) The platform consists of five modules: reagent storage, mixing, activation loops, coupling, and UVâvis analytics. Within the reagent storage are multiple containers of Fmoc-protected amino acids, peptide coupling reagents, Hunigâs base (for coupling), and 40% piperidine in DMF for Fmoc-deprotection. Using a series of pumps and valves, different amino acids are activated with a peptide coupling reagent and base and loaded onto a ChemMatrix PEG resin (Figure 27). Following a wash of this resin and deprotection using piperidine, an additional amino acid can be coupled using the same protocol. It is reported that only 40 s is required for each new amino acid synthesis. Final peptides are cleaved from the resin via batch processes and purified via reverse phase HPLC. This flow technique allows polypeptides to be rapidly synthesized and with much greater purity and conversion in comparison to traditional batch chemistry techniques.

    6. Integrated Flow Systems: Synthesis to Bioassay

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    From the perspective of medicinal chemistry programs, extending automated flow synthesis platforms to include bioassay has the potential to speed up the pace of drug discovery. Cycle times in discovery are defined as the amount of time required to design, synthesize, purify, and screen compounds, using the resultant bioassay data to make decisions on future compounds to prepare. In many cases across the pharmaceutical industry, however, biological assays occur on a scheduled basis (weekly, biweekly, etc.), meaning that cycle times have little room for improvement. To achieve optimal cycle times, having the bioassay integrated with the synthesis has been explored by multiple research groups.
    The idea of integrated synthesisâpurificationâbioassay platforms was first demonstrated by GSK.(149) In the approach described therein, compounds are synthesized, passed through an LC column, and split. When UV/MS detects product, the split aliquot is sent to a fluorescence assay. While only a limited number of samples are reported in this work, this early example demonstrates the ability to rapidly generate structure activity relationships from a single platform. A number of research groups in both academia and industry have subsequently expanded upon this work in efforts to drive down drug discovery cycle times.
    While multiple examples of using flow chemistry to rapidly synthesize new compounds have been reported, many examples do not include a fully integrated bioassay. Using multistep flow chemistry enabled by the use of supported reagents and scavengers, the Ley group has reported the synthesis GABAA agonist libraries used in conjunction with a frontal affinity chromatography (FAC) assay (Scheme 78).(150) A series of autosamplers and fraction collectors are used to facilitate library production, generating 22 analogs within 4 days. Samples for the offline FAC assay can be prepared in a manual or automated manner, prior to being screened in the FAC assay. While the design and implementation of a platform such as this can be resource intensive, the equipment is still housed within a single standard-sized fume hood.
    Researchers at Hoffman-LaRoche have described a fully integrated synthesisâpurificationâbioassay platform to rapidly generate SAR for BACE1 inhibitors.(151) In this work, reactions are carried out in flow, purified via preparative HPLC and analyzed using a chip-based assay. A 2 Ã 10 matrix library of amides (2 anilines Ã10 carboxylic acids) was prepared in flow and purified (Scheme 79). Aliquots of the pure fraction are analyzed by analytical HPLC and quantitated via ELSD, prior to being run in the assay. For each compound in the library, the total time required for synthesis, purification, and bioassay is reported to be 60 min (Figure 28). By greatly reducing the cycle times, this platform demonstrates the ability to make drug discovery more efficient.
    At AbbVie, the SWIFT platform was modified to assist with quantitation and preparation of bioassay samples.(143) While these processes solved many issues related to the dispersal of materials, assays still were not run on-demand. In 2017, a new synthesis and purification platform was developed that incorporates bioassay into its workflow. Using an automated batch chemistry platform, libraries of compounds are now capable of being synthesized, purified, and tested within 24 h, thus greatly reducing cycle times for early stage discovery programs.(152) However, similar to the example reported by Hoffman-LaRoche, libraries are carried out using a predetermined set of monomers and results from the assay cannot be used âon-the-flyâ to make decisions about future compounds to make. To further increase the impact of these integrated systems, algorithms can be incorporated to predict SAR and assist with library design.
    It is with the work of Cyclofluidic that the drug discovery cycle has been fully integrated into a continuous workflow (Figure 29). In this platform, synthesis is carried out using a Vapourtec flow reactor, and aliquots of each reaction are purified and screened in a bioassay. Compounds are selected for synthesis using a series of algorithms to predict potency and expand chemical space. Following the synthesis and bioassay of each compound, the algorithms are updated to assist with the design of future compounds.
    In the first reported example, the Cyclofluidic platform is used to generate SAR for a series of Abl kinase inhibitors.(153) Using a Sonogashira coupling in flow, a series of alkynes are synthesized and screened against Abl (Scheme 80). The targeted chemical space for this examples include 270 virtual compounds (10 aryl halides and 27 alkynes). In the first round of SAR generation, 22 compounds were synthesized and screened within 30 h, assisting with the learning of the activity algorithm and providing a heat map of potency across the chemical space. A second round of SAR was generated following up on active compounds from the first experiment, followed by a final set of experiments geared toward finding more active compounds and refining the heat map of the chemical space. In total, 64 compounds from the virtual space of 270 were synthesized and screened (â¼90 min cycle for each compound), rapidly optimizing this chemical series and providing multiple spots to be followed up by medicinal chemists.
    As with the development of any new technology, there can be a reluctance to accept a platform and data generated may not be trusted. Particularly, this appears to be the case when bioassay data are involved. If assays are run via two separate methods, which can be trusted? In a joint collaboration between Sanofi-Aventis and Cyclofluidics, a series of DPP4 inhibitors were synthesized and screened using the traditional medicinal chemistry approach and the integrated synthesisâbioassay platform.(154) The synthesis involved the coupling of a Boc-protected diamine or amino alcohol with a xanthine starting material, followed by deprotection (Scheme 81). A total of 29 compounds were synthesized and screened within 3 days. Gratifyingly, the data obtained using the two techniques had excellent correlation (R2 > 0.92), validating this integrated platform.
    More recently, the Cyclofluidic platform has been demonstrated to rapidly synthesize and analyze a series of hepsin inhibitors.(155) A series of commercially available analogs were initially screened to provide an initial starting point for library synthesis. Of these compounds, compounds of reasonable potency and selectivity were deconstructed to determine which substrates were more amenable to facile structure modifications (Scheme 82).
    A continuous flow process was developed that could rapidly synthesize analogs of a commercially available amidine, starting from protected amino acids (Scheme 83). Using the CyclOps platform from Cyclofluidic, a small aliquot of the final reaction stream is purified via HPLC/MS prior to being run in the assay. Monomer selection is based upon best objective undersampled (BOUS), where an algorithm predicts potency values and determines which compounds should be prepared first. Following synthesis and assay, the algorithm is updated with experimental data, and a new set of compounds is selected for synthesis. In total, 142 analogs of the 5472 virtual analogs were synthesized, and IC50 values were improved from 1 Î¼M down to 20 nM, with an improved >6000-fold selectivity over uPA.

    7. Reaction Optimization and High-Throughput Experimentation

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    To further accelerate the development of APIs in the pharmaceutical industry, companies have begun to invest in new technologies that can be used in reaction optimization or in high-throughput experimentation.(156) With the help of automation, these tools can be remarkably powerful in shortening the development time associated with compounds of interest.
    Design-of-experiments (DoE) has been reported in many instances using automated flow reactors.(22,25,56,145) DoE enables the multiparameter optimization of continuous variables and can also be used to optimize discrete variables (such as solvent or catalylst) when platforms use advanced algorithms such as SNOBFIT.(157,158) In many circumstances, the results of the initial experiments can be fed back into the algorithm which provides the next experiments to be run. By doing so, a number of synthetic transformations can be optimized using a limited number of reactions and saving material in the process.
    The Bourne research group has demonstrated the automated optimization of the amidation of methyl nicotinate 114 using quantitation via mass spectrometry (Scheme 84).(159) In this example, results of the experiment were fed back into the SNOBFIT algorithm, which determined the next reactions to be run (Figure 30). After running 21 different reactions, a set of conditions was determined generating methyl nicotinate 115 in >90% yield. A similar approach for reaction optimization was carried out by the Jensen group, this time using online IR analysis to optimize the PaalâKnorr reaction.(160)
    Automated reaction optimization has been carried out using SNOBFIT in the context of oscillatory droplets. Abolhasani and co-workers have developed an oscillatory microdroplet approach to optimizing hydroformylation reactions using a tube-in-tube reactor (Figure 31).(161) Reaction droplets containing substrates are passed with a gas-permeable tube which is pressurized with gas in the outer tube. A series of both continuous and discrete variables were optimized using this system, leading to excellent conversion. In total, the SNOBFIT algorithm used 43 reactions for optimization, requiring less than 1 mL total reagent volume.
    Jensen and co-workers have elaborated on this microdroplet reaction optimization by determining conditions for the photoredox decarboxylative cross-coupling using iridiumânickel dual catalysis (Figure 32).(162) Both continuous variables (temperature and time) and discrete variables (catalyst and base) involved in the formation of CâC (sp2âsp3) bonds by this method were optimized. Upon determination of optimal reaction conditions, the reaction was scaled-up in continuous flow photoreactor (Vapourtec UV-150) in order to scale up the reactions to 100â900 mg/h. Low-yielding batch reactions were further optimized using the setup.
    The Jensen and Jamison groups at MIT have developed a highly configurable flow synthesis platform capable of conducting automated optimizations on a series of pharmaceutically relevant transformations (such as Suzuki couplings, BuchwaldâHartwig aminations, photoredox, and SNAr).(163) This plug-and-play platform permits a number of different reactor types to be connected, allowing either single step or multistep sequences to be readily optimized (Figure 33). Again, the SNOBFIT algorithm is used in the automated optimization of reaction conditions. Anywhere from three to five variables can be used in the optimization, and results are obtained within 7â34 h depending on the number of conditions screened. Following optimization, the platform could further be used to scale up individual reactions in upward of 3 g/h.
    In the area of high-throughput experimentation (HTE), Sach and co-workers have developed an automated screening platform capable of screening >1500 reaction conditions during a 24 h period (Figure 34).(164) The platform described therein is capable of screening nanomole-scale reaction using 5 Î¼L reactions segments that are directly analyzed via UPLCâMS. To achieve this, a well-plate autosampler is used to mix microliter quantities of up to 196 starting materials, creating segments that are injected into the reactor coil. The reaction solvent is varied by injecting the reaction segment into the main flow path, which can be 12 different solvents. The segment diffuses into the bulk solvent, thus giving the reaction properties of the bulk solvent and not the stock solution solvent. Analysis is carried out using two UPLCâMS instruments, which are responsible for analyzing segments on an alternating basis. The authors screened a total of 5760 conditions for the Suzuki coupling in which optimal conditions could readily be translated to scale up in both flow and batch. This technique is particularly well-suited to drug discovery organizations where compounds of interest can oftentimes be a limiting factor in deciding to run HTE screens.

    8. Conclusion and Outlook

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    As the field of flow chemistry continues to develop, new applications to the pharmaceutical industry are being realized. While the initial uptake of flow chemistry was slow, an increasing number of reports apply this technology to the synthesis of complex structures, oftentimes on gram to kilogram scale. Challenges such as the proper handling of solids and managing long reaction times will likely persist, but as the field develops, so too will the technologies that can be used to overcome these hurdles.
    Perhaps the area where the benefits of flow chemistry are most apparent is in the development of fast, cryogenic reactions. Not only do these processes demonstrate improved safety via control of exotherms, in many cases the syntheses is amenable to rapid scale-up. One fascinating aspect of this type of system is the amount of material that can be generated from a relatively small-footprint reactor. Setups such as this can have an output of grams to kilograms of product per hour. Although many believe that flow chemistry is a field that requires highly specialized equipment, custom solutions are readily available for all applications which should limit barriers to implementation.
    A once-neglected chemistry technology, photochemistry, is becoming relevant once again due to enhanced reaction profiles and scalability in flow. Moving forward, it is predicted that the use of flow photochemistry will continue to expand, specifically as more photoredox-mediated carbonâcarbon and carbonânitrogen bond forming methodologies are reported. Complementary to photoredox chemistry is electrochemistry, a field relatively in its infancy in flow. As more cross-coupling reactions are enabled by electrochemistry, it too is likely to become adapted more widely in pharma. Only time will tell how these technologies will apply to a manufacturing environment, but as with other applications, flow offers the opportunity of making both of these methodologies safer and more scalable. Indeed, the biggest challenges for both of these fields will be demonstrating scalability past gram scale. Significant research in both academic and industrial settings will assist in establishing new reactor designs that can be used to take this chemistry to the next level.
    Multistep flow syntheses have evolved in an amazing manner over the past 12 years. Using modular reactor designs and additional workup/purification tools permits APIs to be synthesized from a single standalone unit. Similar technologies have also been applied to manufacturing settings to prepare kilograms of material in a day. More examples of continuous manufacturing will be highlighted in years to come using this technology, especially as more companies invest in flow infrastructure. That being said, if it does not make sense for an API to be made in a completely continuous manner, the synthesis can be broken down into multiple highly efficient flow operations, as described by Eli Lilly.
    The combination of automated flow chemistry and machine learning has also found a home in the pharmaceutical industry. As more advance algorithms are used, the pharmaceutical industry can make significant gains in efficiency at all stages of the pipeline. From a medicinal chemistry perspective, this technology can be used to rapidly make SAR, driving candidates toward nomination at a faster rate. Synthetic routes can also be optimized using predictive models that will reduce the development time of an API. Developing âsmartâ flow reactors with automation will likely benefit chemists across all of the pharmaceutical industry. From experience, for this to be successful, there has to be great alignment across various organizations. Chemists, engineers, management, and stakeholders need to have shared goals on these projects and ensure the system is filling a specific gap within the company.
    Flow biocatalysis is another field that is poised for rapid expansion over the next few years. As an increasing number of biocatalytic routes are described in the literature, it is likely that uses of these enzymes in flow (via immobilization) become more widespread and that flow systems are used for high-throughput reaction screening of enzymes. Similar to the immobilized catalysts commonly used in flow, immobilized enzymes offer long-term use, ease of purification, and prevention of downstream reaction fouling. With increased scalability will come increased use across the industry.
    Applying many of these techniques in industry can be a pretty large departure from the norm. Flow chemistry now enables a chemist to consider routes that might involve atypical solutions such as high temperatures (>250 Â°C), unstable intermediates, diazomethane, or photochemistry. For these platforms to be successful, scientists need to continue to challenge the status quo with the implementation of these platforms. As with all the aforementioned technologies, demonstrations of utility will be required to gain a broad acceptance across all stages of the pharmaceutical industry.

    StratoSpheres sulfonic acid functionalized silica

    tR

    residence time

    TBADT

    tetrabutylammonium decatungstate

      1
      Advanced organic synthesis using microreactor technology
      Ahmed-Omer, Batoul; Brandt, Johan C.; Wirth, Thomas
      Organic & Biomolecular Chemistry (2007), 5 (5), 733-740CODEN: OBCRAK; ISSN:1477-0520. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
      A review. Org. synthesis in microreactors is a novel way of performing reactions in a highly controlled way. The benefits of microreactors result from their phys. properties, such as enhanced mass and heat transfer as well as regular flow profiles leading to improved yields with increased selectivities.
      >> More from SciFinder Â®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD2sXhvFSlsr8%253D&md5=44805ff090706707453ea27f00ade015

    3. 3
      Gutmann, B.; Cantillo, D.; Kappe, C. O. Continuous-flow technology-a tool for the safe manufacturing of active pharmaceutical ingredients. Angew. Chem., Int. Ed. 2015, 54 (23), 6688â 6728, Â DOI: 10.1002/anie.201409318
      [Crossref], [CAS],Â Google Scholar
      3
      Continuous-Flow Technology-A Tool for the Safe Manufacturing of Active Pharmaceutical Ingredients
      Gutmann, Bernhard; Cantillo, David; Kappe, C. Oliver
      Angewandte Chemie, International Edition (2015), 54 (23), 6688-6728CODEN: ACIEF5; ISSN:1433-7851. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
      A review. In the past few years, continuous-flow reactors with channel dimensions in the micro- or millimeter region have found widespread application in org. synthesis. The characteristic properties of these reactors are their exceptionally fast heat and mass transfer. In microstructured devices of this type, virtually instantaneous mixing can be achieved for all but the fastest reactions. Similarly, the accumulation of heat, formation of hot spots, and dangers of thermal runaways can be prevented. As a result of the small reactor vols., the overall safety of the process is significantly improved, even when harsh reaction conditions are used. Thus, microreactor technol. offers a unique way to perform ultrafast, exothermic reactions, and allows the execution of reactions which proceed via highly unstable or even explosive intermediates. This Review discusses recent literature examples of continuous-flow org. synthesis where hazardous reactions or extreme process windows have been employed, with a focus on applications of relevance to the prepn. of pharmaceuticals.
      >> More from SciFinder Â®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2MXosVGnt7k%253D&md5=49251387f0f3378dff4e710afe9fbca8
    4. 4
      Hartman, R. L.; McMullen, J. P.; Jensen, K. F. Deciding whether to go with the flow: evaluating the merits of flow reactors for synthesis. Angew. Chem., Int. Ed. 2011, 50 (33), 7502â 7519, Â DOI: 10.1002/anie.201004637
      [Crossref], [CAS],Â Google Scholar
      4
      Deciding whether to go with the flow: evaluating the merits of flow reactors for synthesis
      Hartman, Ryan L.; McMullen, Jonathan P.; Jensen, Klavs F.
      Angewandte Chemie, International Edition (2011), 50 (33), 7502-7519, S7502/1-S7502/3CODEN: ACIEF5; ISSN:1433-7851. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
      A review. The fine chems. and pharmaceutical industries are transforming how their products are manufd., where economically favorable, from traditional batchwise processes to continuous flow. This evolution is impacting synthetic chem. on all scales-from the lab. to full prodn. This article discusses the relative merits of batch and micro flow reactors for performing synthetic chem. in the lab.

The current article reviews routes to approved drugs that employ at least one continuous flow step, disclosed in the patent literature during 2016 and 2017, with a further constraint that the chem. has not been published in a journal article.

      Applying Flow Chemistry: Methods, Materials, and Multistep Synthesis
      McQuade, D. Tyler; Seeberger, Peter H.
      Journal of Organic Chemistry (2013), 78 (13), 6384-6389CODEN: JOCEAH; ISSN:0022-3263. (American Chemical Society)
      A review. The synthesis of complex mols. requires control over both chem. reactivity and reaction conditions. While reactivity drives the majority of chem. discovery, advances in reaction condition control have accelerated method development/discovery. Recent tools include automated synthesizers and flow reactors. In this Synopsis, the authors describe how flow reactors have enabled chem. advances in their groups in the areas of single-stage reactions, materials synthesis, and multistep reactions. In each section, the authors detail the lessons learned and propose future directions.

      [ACS Full Text ], [CAS],Â Google Scholar
      10
      The Hitchhiker's Guide to Flow Chemistry
      Plutschack, Matthew B.; Pieber, Bartholomaeus; Gilmore, Kerry; Seeberger, Peter H.
      Chemical Reviews (Washington, DC, United States) (2017), 117 (18), 11796-11893CODEN: CHREAY; ISSN:0009-2665. (American Chemical Society)
      Flow chem. involves the use of channels or tubing to conduct a reaction in a continuous stream rather than in a flask. Flow equipment provides chemists with unique control over reaction parameters, enhancing reactivity or in some cases enabling new reactions. This relatively young technol. has received a remarkable amt. of attention in the past decade with many reports on what can be done in flow. Until recently, however, the question, "Should we do this in flow" has merely been an afterthought. This review introduces readers to the basic principles and fundamentals of flow chem. and critically discusses recent flow chem. accounts.
      >> More from SciFinder Â®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2sXpt1Siu7c%253D&md5=d95f9e3c3cc5ed69d5ba5347eedd9ae9

Pharmaceutical roundtable study demonstrates the value of continuous manufacturing in the design of greener processes. Org. Process Res. Dev. 2013, 17 (12), 1472â 1478, Â DOI: 10.1021/op400245s

      Pharmaceutical Roundtable Study Demonstrates the Value of Continuous Manufacturing in the Design of Greener Processes
      Poechlauer, Peter; Colberg, Juan; Fisher, Elizabeth; Jansen, Michael; Johnson, Martin D.; Koenig, Stefan G.; Lawler, Michael; Laporte, Thomas; Manley, Julie; Martin, Benjamin; O'Kearney-McMullan, Anne
      Organic Process Research & Development (2013), 17 (12), 1472-1478CODEN: OPRDFK; ISSN:1083-6160. (American Chemical Society)
      A review. The American Chem. Society (ACS) Green Chem. Institute (GCI) Pharmaceutical Roundtable conducted a study to elucidate the value of continuous processing, which had been defined as a key research area for green engineering. In the course of defining the business case for continuous processing, individual cases were collected and evaluated to det. specific drivers to implement continuous processing and to find key success factors. The magnitude and timing of effects and the relation to the principles of green chem. were investigated.
      >> More from SciFinder Â®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC3sXhvVajtbjM&md5=bdaa738462e6ac6ebf86aa8459efbf14
    12. 12
      Porta, R.; Benaglia, M.; Puglisi, A. Flow chemistry: recent developments in the synthesis of pharmaceutical products. Org. Process Res. Dev. 2016, 20 (1), 2â 25, Â DOI: 10.1021/acs.oprd.5b00325
      [ACS Full Text ], [CAS],Â Google Scholar
      12
      Flow Chemistry: Recent Developments in the Synthesis of Pharmaceutical Products
      Porta, Riccardo; Benaglia, Maurizio; Puglisi, Alessandra
      Organic Process Research & Development (2016), 20 (1), 2-25CODEN: OPRDFK; ISSN:1083-6160. (American Chemical Society)
      A review. Recently, application of the flow technologies for the prepn. of fine chems., such as natural products or Active Pharmaceutical Ingredients (APIs), has become very popular, esp. in academia. Although pharma industry still relies on multipurpose batch or semibatch reactors, it is evident that interest is arising toward continuous flow manufg. of org. mols., including highly functionalized and chiral compds. Continuous flow synthetic methodologies can also be easily combined to other enabling technologies, such as microwave irradn., supported reagents or catalysts, photochem., inductive heating, electrochem., new solvent systems, 3D printing, or microreactor technol. This combination could allow the development of fully automated process with an increased efficiency and, in many cases, improved sustainability. It has been also demonstrated that a safer manufg. of org. intermediates and APIs could be obtained under continuous flow conditions, where some synthetic steps that were not permitted for safety reasons can be performed with min. risk. In this review we focused our attention only on very recent advances in the continuous flow multistep synthesis of org. mols. which found application as APIs, esp. highlighting the contributions described in the literature from 2013 to 2015, including very recent examples not reported in any published review. Without claiming to be complete, we will give a general overview of different approaches, technologies, and synthetic strategies used so far, thus hoping to contribute to minimize the gap between academic research and pharmaceutical manufg. A general outlook about a quite young and relatively unexplored field of research, like stereoselective organocatalysis under flow conditions, will be also presented, and most significant examples will be described; our purpose is to illustrate all of the potentialities of continuous flow organocatalysis and offer a starting point to develop new methodologies for the synthesis of chiral drugs. Finally, some considerations on the perspectives and the possible, expected developments in the field are briefly discussed.
      >> More from SciFinder Â®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2MXhvFWmurfL&md5=2dbb53679df39f79b957a244c5d57fc5

      Microwave Promoted Transcarbamylation Reaction of Sulfonylcarbamates under Continuous-Flow Conditions
      Kumpina, Ilze; Isaksson, Rebecka; Saevmarker, Jonas; Wannberg, Johan; Larhed, Mats
      Organic Process Research & Development (2016), 20 (2), 440-445CODEN: OPRDFK; ISSN:1083-6160. (American Chemical Society)
      Successful conditions for the transcarbamylation/transesterification reaction of sulfonylcarbamates with alcs. by microwave heating under continuous-flow conditions were developed. After optimization of the processes, two series of O-alkylsulfonylcarbamates were obtained in high yields and purities using microwave transparent borosilicate tube reactors. In order to also illustrate the usefulness of the protocol in a medicinal chem. context, the methodol. was used for the synthesis of three angiotensin II type 2 receptor ligands.

      Synthesis of Annulated Pyridines by Intramolecular Inverse-Electron-Demand Hetero-Diels-Alder Reaction under Superheated Continuous Flow Conditions
      Martin, Rainer E.; Morawitz, Falk; Kuratli, Christoph; Alker, Andre M.; Alanine, Alexander I.
      European Journal of Organic Chemistry (2012), 2012 (1), 47-52CODEN: EJOCFK; ISSN:1099-0690. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
      Pyrimidine alkynes can be transformed into the corresponding annulated pyridines efficiently in flow. The relative rate of reactivity for a series of structurally close starting materials was investigated and a scalable flow process was developed, providing facile access to a series of novel annulated pyridine building blocks. The effect of thermal vol. expansion of solvents under superheated conditions was found to be significant and influenced the residence times considerably.

      The Kondrat'eva Reaction in Flow: Direct Access to Annulated Pyridines
      Lehmann, Johannes; Alzieu, Thibaut; Martin, Rainer E.; Britton, Robert
      Organic Letters (2013), 15 (14), 3550-3553CODEN: ORLEF7; ISSN:1523-7052. (American Chemical Society)
      A continuous flow inverse-electron-demand Kondrat'eva reaction has been developed that provides direct access to cycloalka[c]pyridines from unactivated oxazoles and cycloalkenes. The cycloaddns. of both unactivated alkenes and deactivated oxazoles are promoted in continuous flow at elevated temps. and pressures (230 Â°C, 750psi). E.g., reaction of 5-phenyloxazole and cyclopentene in presence of TFA gave 55% 4-phenyl-6,7-dihydro-5H-cyclopenta[c]pyridine (I). Annulated pyridines obtained by this one-step process are valuable scaffolds for medicinal chem.

      Nucleophilic aromatic substitution of heterocycles using a high-temperature and high-pressure flow reactor
      Charaschanya, Manwika; Bogdan, Andrew R.; Wang, Ying; Djuric, Stevan W.
      Tetrahedron Letters (2016), 57 (9), 1035-1039CODEN: TELEAY; ISSN:0040-4039. (Elsevier Ltd.)
      The authors report herein a high-temp. and high-pressure continuous-flow protocol to carry out nucleophilic arom. substitution (SNAr) of heterocycles with nitrogen nucleophiles. Using the Phoenix Flow Reactor in parallel with Design-of-Expt. software enabled rapid optimization of the SNAr protocol. This protocol facilitated efficient synthesis of a broad range of 2-aminoquinazolines, and was extended to 2-aminoquinoxalines and 2-aminobenzimidazoles.

      Synthesis of Condensed Heterocycles by the Gould-Jacobs Reaction in a Novel Three-Mode Pyrolysis Reactor
      Lengyel, Laszlo Csaba; Sipos, Gellert; Sipocz, Tamas; Vago, Terez; Dorman, Gyorgy; Gerencser, Janos; Makara, Gergely; Darvas, Ferenc
      Organic Process Research & Development (2015), 19 (3), 399-409CODEN: OPRDFK; ISSN:1083-6160. (American Chemical Society)
      In the present paper we report the synthesis of condensed pyrimidone heterocycles (including novel ones) prepd. by the Gould-Jacobs reaction using an inhouse-built vacuum-to-high pressure multipurpose "three-mode" pyrolysis reactor. Four of the ring systems have not been described in the literature to date [e.g., I â II (96%)]. The pyrolysis reactor has (i) a flash vacuum pyrolysis (FVP) module that applies high vacuum (10-3 mbar), letting the starting material through the reactor chamber heated up to 1000 Â°C; (ii) a pneumatic spray pyrolysis (PSP) module that can inject nonvolatile reactants to the heated reactor zone; and (iii) a high-pressure pyrolysis (HPP) continuous-flow module that operates from atm. to 400 bar pressure and between room temp. and 600 Â°C. The capabilities of the pyrolysis reactor were demonstrated by comparison expts. on two different condensed pyrimidone bicyclic ring systems, and the established reaction conditions were then successfully applied to the synthesis of another six condensed pyrimidone bicyclic systems.
      >> More from SciFinder Â®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2MXivF2quro%253D&md5=650c0a823694744335a62e9269ea3848

      Highly efficient thermal cyclization reactions of alkylidene esters in continuous flow to give aromatic/heteroaromatic derivatives
      Lengyel, Laszlo; Nagy, Tibor Zs.; Sipos, Gellert; Jones, Richard; Dorman, Gyoergy; Uerge, Laszlo; Darvas, Ferenc
      Tetrahedron Letters (2012), 53 (7), 738-743CODEN: TELEAY; ISSN:0040-4039. (Elsevier Ltd.)
      Intramol. thermal cyclization and benzannulation reactions of the Gould-Jacobs and Conrad-Limpach types were performed in a designed continuous flow reactor system at temps. in the range of 300-360Â° and under high pressure conditions (100-160 bar) with very short residence times (0.45-4.5 min) in THF as a low-b.p. solvent. Substituted heteroarom. compds. including pyridopyrimidinones and hydroxyquinolines were synthesized in moderate to high yields. Application of the reaction conditions also allows the synthesis of naphthol and biphenyl derivs. The procedure involves an easy work-up and the non-batchwise preparative synthesis method is suitable for automation.

      Synthesis of Fused Pyrimidinone and Quinolone Derivatives in an Automated High-Temperature and High-Pressure Flow Reactor
      Tsoung, Jennifer; Bogdan, Andrew R.; Kantor, Stanislaw; Wang, Ying; Charaschanya, Manwika; Djuric, Stevan W.
      Journal of Organic Chemistry (2017), 82 (2), 1073-1084CODEN: JOCEAH; ISSN:0022-3263. (American Chemical Society)
      Fused pyrimidinone and quinolone derivs. that are of potential interest to pharmaceutical research were synthesized within minutes in up to 96% yield in an automated Phoenix high-temp. and high-pressure continuous flow reactor. Heterocyclic scaffolds that are either hard to synthesize or require multisteps are readily accessible using a common set of reaction conditions. The use of low-boiling solvents along with the high conversions of these reactions allowed for facile workup and isolation. The methods reported herein are highly amenable for fast and efficient heterocycle synthesis as well as compd. scale-ups.

      Expedient Diels-Alder cycloadditions with ortho-quinodimethanes in a high temperature/pressure flow reactor
      Tsoung, Jennifer; Wang, Ying; Djuric, Stevan W.
      Reaction Chemistry & Engineering (2017), 2 (4), 458-461CODEN: RCEEBW; ISSN:2058-9883. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
      Diels-Alder cycloaddns. enabled by the efficient ring-opening of benzocyclobutenes such as (bicyclo[4.2.0]octa-1,3,5-trien-7-ylmethoxy)dimethyl(vinyl)silane, N-(cyanomethyl)bicyclo[4.2.0]octa-1,3,5-triene-7-carboxamide, (E)-7-((cinnamyloxy)methyl)bicyclo[4.2.0]octa-1,3,5-triene, etc. and benzothiophene-2,2-dioxides such as 1-(2,2-dioxidobenzo[c]isothiazol-1(3H)-yl)pent-4-en-1-one, 1-(pent-4-en-1-yl)-1,3-dihydrobenzo[c]isothiazole 2,2-dioxide, N-allyl-N-benzyl-2-(2,2-dioxido-1,3-dihydrobenzo[c]thiophen-1-yl)acetamide, N-allyl-2-(2,2-dioxido-1,3-dihydrobenzo[c]thiophen-1-yl)acetamide using a high temp./pressure flow reactor has been described. The resultant ortho-quinodimethanes were generated and subsequently reacted with a wide range of dienophiles to provide complex heterocyclic ring systems, e.g., I. The use of flow technol. allowed these reactions to be completed within minutes using conventional, readily removed solvents.

      High-Temperature Boc Deprotection in Flow and Its Application in Multistep Reaction Sequences
      Bogdan, Andrew R.; Charaschanya, Manwika; Dombrowski, Amanda W.; Wang, Ying; Djuric, Stevan W.
      Organic Letters (2016), 18 (8), 1732-1735CODEN: ORLEF7; ISSN:1523-7052. (American Chemical Society)

      28
      Rapid and efficient trifluoromethylation of aromatic and heteroaromatic compounds using potassium trifluoroacetate enabled by a flow system
      Chen, Mao; Buchwald, Stephen L.
      Angewandte Chemie, International Edition (2013), 52 (44), 11628-11631CODEN: ACIEF5; ISSN:1433-7851. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
      We have developed a simple, scalable, and efficient technique to introduce a trifluoromethyl group into arom. and heteroarom. compds. by copper-mediated cross-coupling reactions. This method represents th e first example of arom. trifluoromethylation conducted in flow, using stable, cost-effective, and easy-to-handle CF3CO2K as the CF3 source. Of importance, very short reaction times (minutes) are required to achieve full conversion of (hetero)-aryl starting materials in this process. To increase the practicality of the protocol, all components used to assemble our reactors are available from com. sources. Moreover, we have also successfully performed a Hammett study using a 1 min residence time at 200 Â°C by employing flow techniques, thus providing a reliable method of studying the reaction under "hot and fast", and synthetically relevant reaction conditions.

      Amann, Franz; Frank, Michael; Rhodes, Robert; Robinson, Andrew; Kesselgruber, Martin; Abele, Stefan
      Organic Process Research & Development (2016), 20 (2), 446-451CODEN: OPRDFK; ISSN:1083-6160. (American Chemical Society)

Trichloroacetimidate 4 is an intermediate for an active pharmaceutical intermediate (API) under development at Actelion Pharmaceuticals Ltd. The instability of compds. 3 and 4 at temps. above 100 Â°C prevented scale-up of the original batch mode procedure to the required multikilogram scale. This problem was solved by developing a flow chem. process used for the successful prodn. of 95 kg of 4.

      Design and Application of a Low-Temperature Continuous Flow Chemistry Platform
      Newby, James A.; Blaylock, D. Wayne; Witt, Paul M.; Pastre, Julio C.; Zacharova, Marija K.; Ley, Steven V.; Browne, Duncan L.
      Organic Process Research & Development (2014), 18 (10), 1211-1220CODEN: OPRDFK; ISSN:1083-6160. (American Chemical Society)
      A flow reactor platform technol. applicable to a broad range of low temp. chem. is reported. The newly developed system captures the essence of running low temp. reactions in batch and represents this as a series of five flow coils, each with independently variable vol. The system was initially applied to the functionalization of alkynes, Grignard addn. reactions, heterocycle functionalization, and heteroatom acetylation. This new platform has then been used in the prepn. of a 20-compd. library of polysubstituted, fluorine-contg. arom. substrates from a sequential metalation-quench procedure and can be readily adapted to provide gaseous electrophile inputs such as carbon dioxide using a tube-in-tube reactor.

      Reconfiguration of a Continuous Flow Platform for Extended Operation: Application to a Cryogenic Fluorine-Directed ortho-Lithiation Reaction
      Newby, James A.; Blaylock, D. Wayne; Witt, Paul M.; Turner, Richard M.; Heider, Patrick L.; Harji, Bashir H.; Browne, Duncan L.; Ley, Steven V.
      Organic Process Research & Development (2014), 18 (10), 1221-1228CODEN: OPRDFK; ISSN:1083-6160. (American Chemical Society)
      A flow platform for prepg. various arom. scaffolds using a low-temp. fluorine-directed ortho-lithiation reaction has been successfully reconfigured to allow large-scale processing over extended reaction periods. During the course of this work several key factors have resulted in the development of new technol. such as stainless steel y-piece fittings capable of hosting a thermocouple at the point of mixing which directly controls the power output of a cryogenic cooling device. These developments have enabled the continuous processing of an industrially relevant product, where adequate mixing, cooling, and exotherm control are important for successful operation. The configuration culminates in a large-scale campaign where the flow platform is utilized to process over 100 g of pure product over 7 h, in a yield of 80% after workup.
      >> More from SciFinder Â®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2cXhsFyjtb3N&md5=9da1342c526f7ae96bdc33b0d80829f2

      A Simple Scale-up Strategy for Organolithium Chemistry in Flow Mode: From Feasibility to Kilogram Quantities
      Hafner, Andreas; Filipponi, Paolo; Piccioni, Lorenzo; Meisenbach, Mark; Schenkel, Berthold; Venturoni, Francesco; Sedelmeier, Joerg
      Organic Process Research & Development (2016), 20 (10), 1833-1837CODEN: OPRDFK; ISSN:1083-6160. (American Chemical Society)
      A platform for conducting organolithium chem. in continuous flow mode, covering the scales from medicinal chem. to later phase process development, is described. The use of this flow setup, which mimics the concept of flash chem. on scale, was demonstrated by the exemplary, large-scale prepn. of (4-fluoro-2-(trifluoromethyl)phenyl)boronic acid following a reaction sequence of halogen/lithium exchange, borylation, and semibatch workup. Also, the key factors and corresponding practical assessments required for the streamlined and seamless scale-up from lab. environment to higher productivity are highlighted.

      Development and scale-up of a flow chemistry lithiation-borylation route to a key boronic acid starting material
      Usutani, Hirotsugu; Nihei, Takashi; Papageorgiou, Charles D.; Cork, David G.
      Organic Process Research & Development (2017), 21 (4), 669-673CODEN: OPRDFK; ISSN:1083-6160. (American Chemical Society)
      A flow chem. process for the synthesis of a key boronic acid starting material was developed utilizing flow flash chem. that allowed formation and subsequent productive reaction of an unstable organolithium intermediate. Rapid scale-up from Discovery Chem. and process optimization to kilogram-scale prodn. was achieved using a short residence time (0.25 s) and noncryogenic temp. (0Â°), without the need to increase the no. of reactors. A comparison of the flow process with a Miyaura borylation process suggested some potential benefit in the overall process operating efficiency from avoiding the use of Pd and genotoxic boron reagents.

      Application of Continuous Flow for DIBAL-H Reduction and n-BuLi Mediated Coupling Reaction in the Synthesis of Eribulin Mesylate
      Fukuyama, Takashi; Chiba, Hiroyuki; Kuroda, Hirofumi; Takigawa, Teiji; Kayano, Akio; Tagami, Katsuya
      Organic Process Research & Development (2016), 20 (2), 503-509CODEN: OPRDFK; ISSN:1083-6160. (American Chemical Society)
      Here we examd. the use of continuous flow conditions for the final assembly of eribulin mesylate aimed to avoid cryogenic condition. The diisobutylaluminum hydride redn. of ester I [R = CO2Me] to aldehyde I [R = CHO] and n-butyllithium-mediated coupling of aldehyde I [R = CHO] and sulfone fragment II to produce sulfone-diol III were investigated. Under optimized continuous flow conditions, both reactions could be run at temps. higher than those used under batch conditions. For the diisobutylaluminum hydride redn. of ester I [R = CO2Me] to aldehyde I [R = CHO], under optimized continuous flow conditions at -50 Â°C, aldehyde I [R = CHO] was afforded with better HPLC area ratio than it was under batch conditions at -70 Â°C. Furthermore, continuous operation for 87 min afforded the same quality of I [R = CHO] as was produced with a short-time operation (yield, 96.5%). For the n-butyllithium-mediated coupling of I [R = CHO] and II, under optimized continuous flow conditions at 10 Â°C, III was afforded with a better conversion rate than it was under batch conditions at -70 Â°C.

      Diisobutylaluminum Hydride Reductions Revitalized: A Fast, Robust, and Selective Continuous Flow System for Aldehyde Synthesis
      Webb, Damien; Jamison, Timothy F.
      Organic Letters (2012), 14 (2), 568-571CODEN: ORLEF7; ISSN:1523-7052. (American Chemical Society)
      A continuous flow system for the multiparameter (flow rate, temp., residence time, stoichiometry) optimization of the DIBALH redn. of esters to aldehydes is described. Incorporating an in-line quench (MeOH), these transformations are generally complete in fewer than 60 s. Mixing of the DIBALH and ester solns. was obsd. to be an exceptionally crit. parameter for optimum results. This system thus provides general guidelines based on the structure of the ester for selective redn. of an ester without overredn.

      Dichloromethyllithium: Synthesis and Application in Continuous Flow Mode
      Hafner, Andreas; Mancino, Valentina; Meisenbach, Mark; Schenkel, Berthold; Sedelmeier, Joerg
      Organic Letters (2017), 19 (4), 786-789CODEN: ORLEF7; ISSN:1523-7052. (American Chemical Society)
      A simple and robust procedure for the synthesis and use of thermally unstable dichloromethyllithium in continuous flow mode is described. By utilizing residence times in the range of milliseconds for the generation and electrophilic quench of dichloromethyllithium, the straightforward synthesis of dichlorocarbinols and benzylic pinacol esters was realized at reaction temps. of -30 Â°C, whereas typical temps. in traditional batch mode are below -78 Â°C. The excellent purity profile obtained from the flow process allows us to directly telescope the exiting flow stream into semibatch quenches for further modifications. All transformations gave the desired products in remarkable purity and yield on gram scale with no need for chromatog.

      Convergent, Kilogram Scale Synthesis of an Akt Kinase Inhibitor
      Grongsaard, Pintipa; Bulger, Paul G.; Wallace, Debra J.; Tan, Lushi; Chen, Qinghao; Dolman, Sarah J.; Nyrop, Jason; Hoerrner, R. Scott; Weisel, Mark; Arredondo, Juan; Itoh, Takahiro; Xie, Chengfu; Wen, Xianghui; Zhao, Dalian; Muzzio, Daniel J.; Bassan, Ephraim M.; Shultz, C. Scott
      Organic Process Research & Development (2012), 16 (5), 1069-1081CODEN: OPRDFK; ISSN:1083-6160. (American Chemical Society)
      The development of a convergent, chromatog.-free synthesis of an allosteric Akt kinase inhibitor is described. The route comprised 17 total steps and was used to produce kilogram quantities of the target mol. A key early transformation, for which both batch and flow protocols were developed, was formylation of a dianion derived by deprotonation and subsequent lithium-halogen exchange from a 2-bromo-3-aminopyridine precursor. Improved reaction yield and practicality were achieved in the continuous processing mode. Further significant process developments included the safe execution of a high temp. and pressure hydrazine displacement, sepn. of substituted cyclobutane diastereomers by means of chemoselective ester hydrolysis, and a late-stage Suzuki fragment coupling under mild conditions.
      >> More from SciFinder Â®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC38XksVKguro%253D&md5=8aa3897b0a2cdfff4040b323aa96c5e5

      Thaisrivongs, D. A.; Naber, J. R.; Rogus, N. J.; Spencer, G. Development of an organometallic flow chemistry reaction at pilot-plant scale for the manufacture of verubecestat. Org. Process Res. Dev. 2018, 22 (3), 403â 408, Â DOI: 10.1021/acs.oprd.7b00385
      [ACS Full Text ], [CAS],Â Google Scholar
      43
      Development of an Organometallic Flow Chemistry Reaction at Pilot-Plant Scale for the Manufacture of Verubecestat
      Thaisrivongs, David A.; Naber, John R.; Rogus, Nicholas J.; Spencer, Glenn
      Organic Process Research & Development (2018), 22 (3), 403-408CODEN: OPRDFK; ISSN:1083-6160. (American Chemical Society)
      A process for the prepn. of I (PMB = 4-MeOC6H4CH2), an intermediate in the prepn. of the potential anti-Alzheimer's agent verubecestat, was prepd. on multikilogram (com.) scale by lithiation of a methanesulfonamide and addn. to a nonracemic sulfinylimine using a flow reactor with a static mixer. The reaction was optimized on mass flow rate, temp., solvent and additive, and mixing, as proton transfer between the products, intermediates, and reactants competed with the desired addn. reaction. IR spectroscopy was used to det. reaction conversion and was shown to correlate well with conversions detd. by HPLC, allowing real-time data on batches to be gathered and thus to demonstrate steady-state operation over multiple hours. IR was also used to show that the lithium methanesulfonamide intermediate did not clog the flow app. under various operating parameters.
      >> More from SciFinder Â®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC1cXjt1yks7Y%253D&md5=d251ed04b7e4c9596bc065318054b1ff

      [ACS Full Text ], [CAS],Â Google Scholar
      44
      Using Flow To Outpace Fast Proton Transfer in an Organometallic Reaction for the Manufacture of Verubecestat (MK-8931)
      Thaisrivongs, David A.; Naber, John R.; McMullen, Jonathan P.
      Organic Process Research & Development (2016), 20 (11), 1997-2004CODEN: OPRDFK; ISSN:1083-6160. (American Chemical Society)
      We report that an organolithium addn. to a chiral ketimine, which because of competitive proton transfer proceeds with only modest yield in batch, can be significantly improved in flow. The transformation was discovered to be highly mixing-sensitive but remarkably temp.-independent in flow, enabling the continuous process to be performed under noncryogenic conditions. Expts. at the kilogram scale provided robust operating conditions that are amenable to implementing this chem. for the manuf. of verubecestat (MK-8931), a drug candidate for the treatment of Alzheimer's disease.

      Efficient Iron-Catalyzed Kumada Cross-Coupling Reactions Utilizing Flow Technology under Low Catalyst Loadings
      Buono, Frederic G.; Zhang, Yongda; Tan, Zhulin; Brusoe, Andrew; Yang, Bing-Shiou; Lorenz, Jon C.; Giovannini, Riccardo; Song, Jinhua J.; Yee, Nathan K.; Senanayake, Chris H.
      European Journal of Organic Chemistry (2016), 2016 (15), 2599-2602CODEN: EJOCFK; ISSN:1099-0690. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
      An efficient continuous flow iron-catalyzed Kumada cross-coupling was developed for the coupling of 2-chloropyrazine and various aryl Grignard reagents in presence of low catalyst loadings (0.5 mol-%). Compared to batch mode, the continuous flow approach overcame the exothermicity which enabled longer catalyst lifetime, facilitated scale-up and significantly improved the yield. This was the first example of flow iron-catalyzed Kumada cross-coupling reactions which addressed scale dependence issues which often plague Kumada reactions carried out in the traditional batch mode.

      Continuous Flow Production of Thermally Unstable Intermediates in a Microreactor with Inline IR-Analysis: Controlled Vilsmeier-Haack Formylation of Electron-Rich Arenes
      van den Broek, Sebastiaan A. M. W.; Leliveld, Jeroen R.; Becker, Rene; Delville, Marielle M. E.; Nieuwland, Pieter J.; Koch, Kaspar; Rutjes, Floris P. J. T.
      Organic Process Research & Development (2012), 16 (5), 934-938CODEN: OPRDFK; ISSN:1083-6160. (American Chemical Society)
      The Vilsmeier-Haack formylation of arom. compds. is a well-established process in org. synthesis, largely driven by the fact that the resulting aldehydes are generally useful intermediates for the synthesis of fine chems. and pharmaceutical products. Industrial-scale prodn., however, is often hampered by laborious procedures requiring the use of hazardous chems. to produce the highly reactive intermediates. In order to circumvent these issues, a flow chem. approach was developed. This article describes the design and semiautomated optimization of the Vilsmeier-Haack formylation in continuous flow and subsequent scale-up to preparative vols. in an intrinsically safe manner.

      Continuous-Flow Preparation and Use of Î²-Chloro Enals Using the Vilsmeier Reagent
      Pellegatti, Laurent; Buchwald, Stephen L.
      Organic Process Research & Development (2012), 16 (8), 1442-1448CODEN: OPRDFK; ISSN:1083-6160. (American Chemical Society)
      The Vilsmeier reagent is used in the prepn. of a wide variety of heterocycles, such as pyrazoles, via formation of Î²-chloroacrolein intermediates. However, use of this extremely reactive reagent on large scale requires special precautions to avoid potentially dangerous exotherms. This article describes the safe prepn. at room temp. of the Vilsmeier reagent under flow conditions for the formation of Î²-chloroacroleins and 3-formylchromones, as well as the use of these in multistep, continuous flow processes for the syntheses of Î²-acrylonitriles and polysubstituted pyrazoles.

      Synthesis of Vildagliptin Utilizing Continuous Flow and Batch Technologies
      Pellegatti, Laurent; Sedelmeier, Jorg
      Organic Process Research & Development (2015), 19 (4), 551-554CODEN: OPRDFK; ISSN:1083-6160. (American Chemical Society)
      The prepn. and utilization of the Vilsmeier reagent (VR) is well-known in the literature with its usefulness and scope being frequently demonstrated in org. synthesis. However, it is an irritant and has a high thermal energy of decompn.; consequently, these factors lead to operational issues on larger scale which suggests approaches whereby the reagent is not isolated. Herein, we report the in-line formation and instantaneous consumption of VR utilizing both conventional batch and flow technologies. The approach was demonstrated by way of the synthesis of Vildagliptin, thereby mitigating potential safety and hygiene hazards.

      Safe and Efficient Phosgenation Reactions in a Continuous Flow Reactor
      Yasukouchi, Hiroaki; Nishiyama, Akira; Mitsuda, Masaru
      Organic Process Research & Development (2018), 22 (2), 247-251CODEN: OPRDFK; ISSN:1083-6160. (American Chemical Society)
      Phosgene is widely used in org. synthesis owing to its high reactivity, utility, and cost efficiency. However, the use of phosgene in batch processes on the industrial scale is challenging owing to its toxicity. An effective method to minimize reaction vols. and mitigate the safety risks assocd. with hazardous chems. is the use of flow reactors. Consequently, we have established a flow reaction system using triphosgene and tributylamine, which affords a homogeneous reaction that avoids clogging issues. In addn., we have demonstrated that this methodol. can be applied to a wide variety of phosgene reactions, including the prepn. of pharmaceutical intermediates, in good to excellent yields.

      Gustafsson, Tomas; Soerensen, Henrik; Ponten, Fritiof
      Organic Process Research & Development (2012), 16 (5), 925-929CODEN: OPRDFK; ISSN:1083-6160. (American Chemical Society)

Two steps of an earlier route were adapted to be performed in continuous flow to avoid issues related to batch procedures, resulting in a robust method with reduced cost of goods and improved product quality. Toxic and reactive reagents and starting materials could be handled in a flow regime, thereby allowing safer and more convenient reaction optimization and prodn.

      Telescoped Flow Process for the Syntheses of N-Aryl Pyrazoles
      Li, Bryan; Widlicka, Daniel; Boucher, Steven; Hayward, Cheryl; Lucas, John; Murray, John C.; O'Neil, Brian T.; Pfisterer, David; Samp, Lacey; VanAlsten, John; Xiang, Yanqiao; Young, Joseph
      Organic Process Research & Development (2012), 16 (12), 2031-2035CODEN: OPRDFK; ISSN:1083-6160. (American Chemical Society)
      N-Aryl pyrazoles were prepd. from anilines in a three step telescoped approach. An aniline was diazotized to give the diazonium fluoroborate, followed by redn. with tin(II) chloride to give the corresponding hydrazine, which in turn reacted with a ketoenamine to give the N-aryl pyrazole. The deprotection of the Me ether was accomplished with PhBCl2 to give the final product. The continuous flow methodol. was used to minimize accumulation of the highly energetic and potentially explosive diazonium salt and hydrazine intermediates to enable the safe scale-up of N-aryl pyrazoles. The heterogeneous reaction mixt. was successfully handled in both lab scale and prodn. scale. A continuous extn. was employed to remove org. impurities from the diazotization step, which eliminated the need for chromatog. in the purifn. of the final N-aryl pyrazole.
